false 12802523 AAM-PDF JECHEM 1575 S2095-4956(20)30625-2 10.1016/j.jechem.2020.08.060 Science Press Fig. 1 A brief timeline for lignocellulose conversion for power generation or energy storage. Fig. 2 Schematic diagrams for the structure of lignocellulosic biomass. (a) The main components of lignocellulose (adapted from [8]); (b) hierarchical structure of woody lignocellulose: H is height, L is length and D is diameter (adapted from [14]). Fig. 3 (a) Overview of biomass thermal-conversion techniques; and (b) the pathways accessible for the pyrolysis of cellulose [50,53,64]. Fig. 4 Simple schematic diagram of bioethanol production from lignocellulosic biomass by separate saccharification and fermentation process. Fig. 5 (a–f) schematic diagrams of DCFCs: (a) Molten hydroxide fuel cell (redrawn after [158]; (b) molten carbonate fuel cell [169]; (c) direct contact solid oxide direct carbon fuel cell [170]; (d) indirect contact solid oxide direct carbon fuel cell [171]; (e) molten carbonate solid oxide direct fuel cell [172]; (f) molten metal solid oxide direct carbon fuel cell [168]; (g) principles of lignocellulosic biomass fueled dual-chamber MFC with addition of electron mediator [173]; and (h) schematic of mediated fuel cell using Fe3+/Fe2+ as cathode electron carriers and MBH/MB+ as anode electron carriers [174] (All the figures are reused with permission from Elsevier). Fig. 6 Lignocellulosic biomass-derived materials for EES devices. Fig. 7 Photographs and SEM images of (a) cellulose aerogel; (b) carbon aerogel (CA-SCD) and (c) activated carbon aerogel (ACA-SCD); SEM images of (d, e) activated CMC aerogels (AC) and inset: photographs of AC; (f) illustration of the fabrication of wood-derived CNFs aerogels. (Figs. are reprinted from (a–c) [270], (d, e) [267] and (f) [246] with reuse permission from Elsevier). Fig. 8 (a) GCD curves tested at different current densities of symmetric FASS cell of cellulose/RGO/AgNPs//cellulose/RGO/AgNPs; (b) the areal (black curve) and volumetric (blue curve) specific capacitance; (c) and (d) Areal and volumetric Ragone plots; (e) schematic illustration of the synthetic procedures for Cu2O/Cu/GCP; (f) schematic diagram (left) and digital photograph (right) of the assembled Cu2O/Cu/GCP//CP asymmetric supercapacitor (Figures are reprinted from [284] for (a–d) and [285] for (e–f) with reprint permission from Elsevier). Fig. 9 (a) The photographic images of GPE membrane; (b) the liquid electrolyte uptake of lignin membrane depends on time; (c) the stress-stain curves of lignin membrane after and before absorption at the rate of 1 mm min−1; (d) typical SEM micrographs of surface of cellulose membrane; (e) the surface of PPC membrane (f) and cross section of PPC membrane; (g) the photograph for PPC-cellulose composite; (h) stress–strain curves of the PP separator, pristine cellulose, pristine PPC and PPC-cellulose composite (Figures are reprinted from [301] for (a–c) and [302] for (d–h) with reprint permission from Elsevier) . Graphical abstract This review has provided the research progress on the utilization of lignocellulosic biomass as feedstock and materials for power generation and energy storage focusing on the chemistry aspects of the processes. Lignocellulosic biomass has attracted great interest in recent years for energy production due to its renewability and carbon–neutral nature. There are various ways to convert lignocellulose to gaseous, liquid and solid fuels via thermochemical, chemical or biological approaches. Typical biomass derived fuels include syngas, bio-gas, bio-oil, bioethanol and biochar, all of which could be used as fuels for furnace, engine, turbine or fuel cells. Direct biomass fuel cells mediated by various electron carriers provide a new direction of lignocellulose conversion. Various metal and non-metal based carriers have been screened for mediating the electron transfer from biomass to oxygen thus generating electricity. The power density of direct biomass fuel cells can be over 100 mW cm−2, which shows promise for practical applications. Lignocellulose and its isolated components, primarily cellulose and lignin, have also been paid considerable attention as sustainable carbonaceous materials for preparation of electrodes for supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries. In this paper, we have provided a state-of-the-art review on the research progress of lignocellulosic biomass as feedstock and materials for power generation and energy storage focusing on the chemistry aspects of the processes. It was recommended that process integration should be performed to reduce the cost for thermochemical and biological conversion of lignocellulose to biofuels, while efforts should be made to increase efficiency and improve the properties for biomass fuelled fuel cells and biomass derived electrodes for energy storage. Keywords Lignocellulosic biomass Cellulose Lignin Power generation Energy storage Electrode materials 1 Introduction Lignocellulose, such as forestry and agricultural residues, represents the most abundant natural biomass in the natural world with an approximate yield of about 200 billion tons [1]. In China, the annual yield of agricultural straw can be as high as 900 million tons with a collectable amount of more than 700 million tons. In recent decades, the use of lignocellulosic biomass as feedstock for energy production as well as materials for energy storage has gained great interest. One of the major reasons for such increasing interest is due to the depletion of fossil resources and the climate changes incurred by large-scale combustion of fossil fuels. Therefore, developing renewable energy and alternative fuels is a promising solution for the situation. Another important reason for the utilization of biomass relies on its renewability with reduction of the net emission of carbon dioxide and wide distribution with easy availability. The major chemical components of lignocellulosic biomass are cellulose, hemicelluloses and lignin, all of which have shown great promise as feedstocks and materials for energy generation. Cellulose is a long-chain homopolymer consisting of a glucose unit with cellobiose as the repeat unit. Cellulose plays the major role in the production of biomass derived biofuels. Very wide applications have also been developed for cellulose-derived functional materials [2]. Hemicelluloses are a group of polysaccharides consisting of branched and shorter chains. Hemicelluloses are also important for biofuels production because they can account for as much as 35% of the biomass weight [3]. Lignin is an irregular and heterogeneous oxygenated polymer of p-propylphenol units, consisting of three monolignols: p-coumaryl, coniferyl, and sinapyl alcohols. Lignin has been paid less attention in the bioconversion of lignocellulosic biomass to biofuels; however, modifications of lignin to produce functional carbon materials for batteries or supercapacitors have attracted more and more interest in recent years [4,5]. Actually, the use of lignocellulosic biomass as fuels has accompanied human history since primitive man-made fire with wood. A brief timeline for the conversion of lignocellulose to energy or energy materials is summarized in Fig. 1 . Wood and straws were widely used as household fuels before coals started to replace wood since the 1910 s. A biomass gasification plant on a commercial scale was even constructed as early as the 1840 s in France. The development of flexible fuel vehicles has boosted the use of bioethanol. Currently, lignocellulosic biomass has been used for electricity generation or syngas production by gasification on a commercial scale. Various chemical, thermochemical and biological technologies have been developed for the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass to energy. Production of biofuels such as bioethanol has already reached commercial scale though the cost still has to be further reduced. Lignocellulosic biomass has also been paid much attention for energy storage since 2000, particularly used as materials for electrode preparation for lithium battery and various fuel cells. Direct conversion of lignocellulosic biomass or its isolated components for electricity by fuel cell technology is a new direction developed in recent years. In this review, we have aimed to provide a state-of-the-art overview for the use of lignocellulosic biomass as renewable feedstock or materials for power generation or energy storage. The challenges and potential development directions of this field are also discussed. 2 Lignocellulosic biomass components and structure 2.1 Overview of lignocellulosic biomass and its properties Lignocellulosic biomass is a carbon neutral and renewable resource including a wide range of sources such as agricultural by-products/residues, energy crops, forest residues, grass [6,7]. It mainly consists of carbohydrates (cellulose and hemicellulose) and lignin, in which these three main biopolymers are associated in non-uniform three-dimensional structures to different degrees as shown in Fig. 2 (a) [8]. Cellulose is the primary carbohydrate making up the lignocellulose cell wall. It forms long and oriented microfibrils, which can form longer and larger fibrils [9]. Hemicelluloses are amorphous, branched and single-chain heterogeneous polysaccharides, which attach to neighboring cellulose fibrils via non-covalent cross-links [10] . Being different from hemicellulose, lignin is a complex crosslinked macromolecule playing an important role in binding the lignocellulose matrix together and strengthens the cell walls [11]. The content, polymerization degree and structures of the major three components depend significantly on the types of lignocellulosic biomass [12]. Generally, cellulose and hemicelluloses in biomass (referring to the total carbohydrates content) account for about 70% of the entire biomass content and are tightly linked to the lignin via hydrogen and covalent bonds that contribute greatly to biomass recalcitrance [13] . 2.2 Main components of lignocellulosic biomass 2.2.1 Cellulose Cellulose was firstly discovered by a French chemist named Anselme Payen in 1838 [15]. It is the essential structural component of plant cell walls of lignocellulosic biomass, which is also the most abundant natural polysaccharide in the world [16]. Cellulose is a linear polymer consisting of D-anhydroglucopyranose units covalently linked by β-(1, 4) glycosidic bonds (Fig. 2(a)) [17,18]. Unlike other glucan polymers, disaccharide cellobiose is the fundamental repeating unit. In general, the linear cellulose chains consist of 500–1400 units [19]. The degree of polymerization of cellulose varies with the source. For cotton-derived cellulose, DP is approximately 15,000 times higher than that of wood-derived cellulose (10,000) [20]. In cellulose, every D-anhydroglucopyranose unit has three hydroxyl groups, which are highly reactive and thus impart on cellulose several characteristic properties such as hydrophilicity and biodegradability [21]. Additionally, interactions of hydroxyl groups also form extensive hydrogen bonding networks including intermolecular and intramolecular types (Fig. 2(a)), which bind the cellulose chains tightly and lead to a multiscale microfibrillated and crystalline structure [16,22]. Cellulose has two forms of structure: crystalline and amorphous. Compared to the crystalline structure, the amorphous structure is easier to degrade by chemical reagents and enzymes because its hydrogen bonding networks are poorly organized. 2.2.2 Hemicelluloses Hemicelluloses are the second abundant carbohydrate of lignocellulosic biomass with a random and amorphous structure [8]. Being different from cellulose, hemicelluloses are a type of heteropolysaccharides, which are comprised of pentoses (D-xylose, L-arabinose), hexoses (D-glucose, D-galactose, D-mannose, D-Rhamnose) (Fig. 2(a)), uronic acid groups (D-galacturonic acid, 4-O-methyl-D-glucuronic acid and D-glucuronic acid) and acetyl groups in varying amounts depending on the plant species [23]. Additionally, hemicelluloses chains are much shorter and with much lower DP (average DP 150–200) than cellulose [24,25]. Hemicelluloses usually have a backbone containing one repeating monosaccharide unit linked by a β-(1 → 4) bond with branch points in (1 → 2), (1 → 3) and (1 → 6) [26]. Hardwood hemicelluloses mostly have a backbone composed of β-1, 4-linked D-xylopyranose units, while hemicelluloses of softwood typically contain β-1, 4-linked D-mannopyranose D- glucopyranose, namely glucomannans. Branch frequencies of hemicellulose depend greatly on the source and nature of biomass. Hemicelluloses are associated with each other through hydrogen and covalent bonds [23]. Being different from crystalline cellulose, hemicelluloses are hydrolyzed more easily to monomeric sugars during thermochemical pretreatment [27]. Hemicelluloses are also believed to be closely linked with cellulose via extensive hydrogen bonds and with lignin mainly through covalent bonds [28]. Because of their interaction with cellulose and lignin, hemicelluloses contribute to improving the mechanical properties of cell walls such as rigidity and flexibility [29]. 2.2.3 Lignin Lignin is the most abundant renewable aromatic polymer in the world and is widely found in higher plant cells, which is majorly cross-linked with hemicelluloses in lignocellulosic biomass through covalent bonds and hydrogen bonds. In lignocellulosic biomass, lignin not only provides structural strength, but also provides stiffness and resistance against pathogens and insects [30]. It is a complex polymer with a non-crystalline and irregular three-dimensional structure, which is mainly composed of three primary units, namely syringyl (S), guaiacyl (G) and p-hydroxyphenyl (H) units (Fig. 2(a)). The composition and distribution of each unit in lignin varies greatly with source. For instance, the lignin of hardwood generally has both G and S units, while softwood lignin mainly consists of G units, and lignin of non-woody biomass has all three units [31]. There are two major linkages in lignin: ether linkages (e.g. α-O-4 and β-O-4) and carbon–carbon linkages (e.g. β-β, β-5, 5–5, β-1) (Fig. 2(a)) [32,33]. Many structural studies have revealed that β-O-4 is the dominant linkage in the native lignin accounting for approximately 50% of total linkages, together with other linkages like β-β (5%–12%), β-5 (1%–12%), 5–5 (1%–9%), β-1 [31,34,35]. Meanwhile, the β-O-4 ether linkage is the most reactive linkage during the depolymerization process, thus cleavage of the β-O-4 ether linkage has been considered as the critical step of lignin depolymerization to utilize lignin as feedstock to produce chemicals, fuels or materials [36]. 2.3 Structural features of lignocellulosic biomass Lignocellulosic biomass is a complex biopolymer that has a hierarchical structure which spans multiple orders of magnitudes in length [37]. Taking wood as an example, the hierarchical structure is shown in Fig. 2(b) [14]. Wood at each length scale has its own structural features enabling specific functions. The ten meters of trunks raise the tree crown to get more sunlight, which is essential for photosynthesis and provides the building material to protect it from natural disasters [14]. At millimeter scale, the primary cells in gymnosperms, also called tracheids, are about 2–4 mm in length and 20–40 μm in diameter, which perform as the structural support and serve for the transportation of water and nutrients [20,38]. Multiple layers with different compositions and nanoscale arrangements of biopolymers (cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin) make up the lignocellulosic cell walls. Typically, lignocellulosic cell walls consist of middle lamella (ML), primary wall (P), and secondary wall (S) layers as shown in Fig. 2(b). The secondary wall is the major part of cell walls, which includes three distinct layers, named S1, S2, and S3. The middle lamella acting to adhere adjacent cells is heavily lignified. In many cases, it is difficult to distinguish the primary wall from the middle lamella and thus these two regions are also termed as “compound middle lamella” [4]. Down to nanometer scale, the 10–20 nm microfibrils formed by elementary cellulose fibrils mainly exist in the S2 layer, which are aligned parallelly with each other at different angles along the axis direction [39]. The 1.5–3.5 nm elementary cellulose fibrils are assembled by individual cellulose chains. Within elementary cellulose fibrils, crystalline regions are interspersed with amorphous regions. In native cellulose, crystalline regions are usually 100–250 nm in length and 3–10 nm in width [20]. Furthermore, the cell wall has a complex pore structure, which can be classified into tissue level, cell level and cell wall levels according to the cell wall organs. According to Zhao and Chen [40], the pores in the tissue level mainly containing cell lumen and intercellular spaces are of the size of 1–130 μm, while the pores in the cell level, mainly referring to the pits in the cell wall, are on the scale of 0.03–50 μm. Additionally, the pores in the cell wall level are of the size in the range of 0.001 to 0.100 μm, which is comprised of the space among biopolymers (e.g., cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin), microfibrils and macrofibrils. The porous nature of lignocellulosic biomass enables it as a good feedstock for producing porous materials such as activated carbon and electrode materials, though modification is needed. 3 Lignocellulosic biomass as feedstock for fuel production 3.1 Thermo-chemical conversion and the chemistry 3.1.1 Overview of thermo-chemical conversion Thermochemical conversion is one of the most important methods for biomass conversion to energy and fuels. Thermochemical conversion can be defined as the controlled heating or oxidation of feedstocks to generate energy products and/or heat. This covers several distinct techniques, primarily including pyrolysis, liquefaction, gasification and combustion (Fig. 3 (a)). The thermochemical conversion techniques differ by their range of conditions and degree of control of both oxidation and heating [41]. Pyrolysis can be described as the initial step of both gasification and combustion processes [42]. Pyrolysis is the thermal decomposition of biomass performed with the exclusion of oxygen while involving the use of inert atmospheres e.g. nitrogen, argon. The process is mostly endothermic, meaning that the products of pyrolysis can be considered to have high energy content. The product mixtures formed are highly heterogeneous, consisting of volatile gaseous products, liquid mixtures and highly-carbonized solid residues, “char” (charcoal, biochar). The non-condensable gases generated are primarily CO2, CO, CH4, H2, C2H6, C2H4 and H2O. The liquid phase, commonly referred to as “pyrolysis oil”, consists of both water and oxygenated aliphatic and aromatic chemicals [43]. The make-up of pyrolysis oils can vary significantly, although they tend to have similar properties. Their water content is typically in the range ~ 15 wt%–30 wt%, with an oxygen content ~ 35%–40% distributed across all pyrolysis products. Whilst this is significantly higher than for standard oil fuels, pyrolysis oils are nonetheless deoxygenated relative to their feedstocks. They also tend to have low pH values (pH 2–3) owing to the presence of carboxylic acids (e.g. acetic acid, formic acid). Common components of pyrolysis oils include acids, alcohols, esters, aldehydes, ketones, sugars, phenols, guaiacols, syringols, furans and functionalised-phenols. It can be seen that these are highly-oxygen containing functionalities [44,45]. Pyrolysis oils can also contain inorganic species (e.g. Ca, Fe, K) either as counter-ions or connected to organic acids [46]. Whilst pyrolysis oils can be used directly as fuels (particularly for generation of heat or power), their oxygen and moisture content, corrosiveness and low pH cause difficulties [43,47,48]. Owing to their low quality, pyrolysis oils generally require further upgrading before they can be applied as transport fuels. The inclusion of catalysts and additives can improve the qualities of pyrolysis oils. For example, the oxygen content can be reduced through hydrotreating (the addition of hydrogen gas to remove oxygen as water) or catalytic cracking which uses shape-selective catalysts e.g. zeolites [49]. Different types of pyrolysis processes are tailored towards the generation of particular products. “Slow pyrolysis” processes are those which use a long residence time (on the order of hours to days) with a low heating rate. This favors the formation of char, and these processes can also be referred to as “carbonization”. A typical product ratio for carbonization processes is 35 wt% char, with 35 wt% gases and 30 wt% pyrolysis oil [50]. A slow heating rate over a long residence time enables a high number of different reactions to take place at different temperatures, operating in equilibrium with each other. This generates a wider product distribution. Reactions such as thermal cracking, repolymerization and condensation can occur over long reaction times which lead to high yields of char. Carbonization processes designed to achieve high yields of char can be performed without significant control of particle size. Larger particles result in a less-uniform heating distribution, as larger particles heat more slowly resulting in a lower average temperature [51]. The burning of charcoal as a fuel dates back to ancient times. The liquid products formed alongside char from “slow pyrolysis” are generally highly viscous with poor water miscibility, reducing their applicability as fuels [52]. To favor the production of pyrolysis oil over char, “fast pyrolysis” processes must be used. These use much higher rates of heating (>10–200 K s−1) and much shorter residence times, typically < 2 sec. The fast rate of heating minimizes the number of reactions taking place during the heating process, such that isothermal reactions occur only at a well-defined final temperature. With fast heating, fragmentation happens quickly, minimizing the formation of char. Short residence times also favor the production of pyrolysis oil by minimizing secondary reactions through removal of organic vapors [50]. Fast pyrolysis also requires the use of smaller particles to achieve more uniform heating: the formation of pyrolysis oils is favored by the use of very fine particles [51]. Volatile gases are more readily removed from fine particles, and upon condensation result in higher yields of pyrolysis oil. In larger particles, vapors are more likely to crack before they can “escape”, forming higher yields of char. Reactions which use even higher heating rates (up to 104 K s−1) and even shorter residence times (< ½ second) are termed as “flash pyrolysis”. The heating must be followed by rapid quenching through cooling, to prevent any further conversions from occurring and to maximize the yield of liquid products, which only condense upon cooling. It is important to separate the char from the liquid vapors as quickly as possible, as char acts as a cracking catalyst [53]. The temperature used is another important factor. Heating above 650 °C favors the gaseous products, whilst slow heating at lower temperatures favors the production of char. As a result of these factors, there tends to be an optimum temperature for the production of pyrolysis oil, by minimizing the formation of both gaseous products (at higher temperature) and solid products (at lower temperature). Yields of up to ~75% liquid product based upon the starting biomass weight can be achieved (with small amounts of both solid char and gases). Compared to the pyrolysis oils formed from slow pyrolysis processes, flash pyrolysis produces oils of much lower viscosity and higher water miscibility [52]. Although the product composition can be tuned by temperature, rate of heating, residence time and particle size, pyrolysis reactions are complicated by the chemical complexity and heterogeneity of biomass. The different components of biomass have different thermal properties and undergo pyrolysis at different temperatures. Hemicellulose generally pyrolyzes at the lowest temperatures, in the range of 210–310 °C. Depending upon the source of biomass, cellulose begins to pyrolyzes around 300–315 °C, ending around 360–380 °C. Whilst lignin begins to pyrolyze in the same temperature range as hemicellulose (~200 °C), its decomposition is more gradual over a temperature range up to 1000 °C [54]. Whilst hemicellulose can be considered to be pyrolyze first, followed by cellulose and lignin, it is difficult to directly relate the biomass composition to the product distribution. This is further complicated by the existence of interactions between the biomass components under pyrolysis conditions [41,55]. A wide range of reactions can take place, including dehydrations, depolymerizations, isomerizations, aromatizations, decarboxylations and charring. Generally, cellulose pyrolyzes to form primarily pyrolysis oil mixtures. Hemicellulose forms primarily non-condensable vapors. Lignin decomposes with release of gases to form chemical intermediates which undergo substitutive additions and cross-linking reactions, tending towards solid char. Typical products of lignin monomers are phenol and phenoxy species [50]. Pyrolysis processes can be significantly affected by the introduction of catalysts. Generally, these aim to reduce the oxygen content of the pyrolysis oil products. Whilst pyrolysis still occurs through thermal depolymerization followed by subsequent decomposition into volatile compounds, acid-catalyzed deoxygenation reactions, including decarboxylation, decarbonylation and dehydration, result in greater formation of hydrocarbon products [56]. The quality of the pyrolysis products can also be improved by the utilization of pretreatment methods. Torrefaction is a low temperature (200–300 °C) thermal pretreatment designed to remove water and other volatiles, producing a solid product with a lower oxygen content and higher energy density than the original biomass feedstock. This is as a result of significant loss of mass but retention of the original energy content. With heating up to 200 °C, free water and physically bound water is released, alongside light volatile fractions. Torrefaction itself begins at 200 °C and ends when the temperature is brought back below 200 °C after heating in a narrow temperature-window. This is designed to decompose the most reactive hemicellulose fraction (without degrading the other biomass components). The resulting solid product is of higher quality for e.g. combustion or gasification. It can be considered as a milder version of pyrolysis, and less structurally-destructive than carbonization [57]. Pyrolysis was defined as thermal decomposition performed in the absence of oxygen, i.e. in an inert atmosphere. When the process is performed in air (a reactive atmosphere) at high temperatures, complete gasification takes place resulting in the formation of gaseous fuel, and a solid residue (ash). The high temperatures used inhibit the formation and condensation of liquid products [58]. The gases produced from gasification include CO, H2 (syngas), CH4 and CO2. In comparison to pyrolysis, the products require less post-treatment. Gasification can be described in three stages. Drying (up to 120 °C) as evaporation of free, and bound, moisture to produce steam; followed by devolatisation, loss of volatile matter from the feedstock and formation of char (up to 350 °C); and gasification of char (above 350 °C). Complete gasification is achieved at temperatures above 500 °C [59]. The presence of oxygen, or air, is necessary for complete gasification (the inert conditions used for pyrolysis instead favor devolatisation, generating higher yields of char). Commonly, sub-stochiometric quantities of air are used for gasification to avoid full combustion of the feedstock [60]. With the introduction of air, combustion takes place through reaction of both char and other volatile products with oxygen. This generates carbon dioxide, alongside carbon monoxide and heat. The gasification reactions themselves involve reaction of char with carbon dioxide and steam (produced from drying of the biomass) to generate hydrogen gas and carbon monoxide. At the high temperatures used for gasification, the reversible water–gas shift reaction is in equilibrium. Therefore, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, water and hydrogen gas are present in equilibrium with each other. In such a way, the introduction of oxygen/air and its subsequent combustion of the biomass material is required to generate carbon dioxide and energy to drive the gasification reactions. Typically, the co-feed of oxygen burns ~25% of the feedstock during gasification [47]. Especially at higher temperatures and pressures, and with longer residence times, carbon monoxide and water can also react to form methane and carbon dioxide. As gasification reactions are designed to produce high yields of fuels gases, cracking and reforming reactions are favored; pyrolysis processes aim to avoid these same reactions [61]. Gasification reactions performed with oxygen, rather than air, produce gases with higher energy-content by avoiding nitrogen dilution (Air-based processes can generate products with up to 60% nitrogen content). However the use of an oxygen supply introduces cost and safety issues [52,58]. Whilst the gases produced through gasification (syngas) can be used for the indirect formation of liquid fuels from biomass, direct liquefaction processes also exist [58]. These differ from pyrolysis processes because they are performed under high pressures of hydrogen gas (up to 150 bar) alongside the use of a catalyst. The feedstock molecules decompose into low molecular-weight, highly reactive fragments in the presence of a catalyst, and repolymerize to form liquid products with suitable molecular weights for fuel applications [42]. The high pressures used allow a liquid phase to be maintained at higher temperatures and enable superior gas transfer. Generally, liquefaction is considered as a less attractive route to liquid products compared to flash pyrolysis. Not only is the use of high pressures of gas more expensive and operationally difficult, the liquid products tend to have less favorable properties and are produced in lower yields. However, owing to the presence of high pressures of a reducing gas (typically hydrogen), the oxygen content is significantly lower than for pyrolysis oils (~15 wt%) [52]. In addition to the “typical” gasification and liquefaction techniques, the use of hydrothermal processes offers some advantages. These are performed in high temperature and pressure liquids or supercritical water. The use of high pressures maintains water in the liquid phase, meaning that the typical energy cost of water evaporation is avoided. Typically, hydrothermal liquefaction takes place at 200–370 °C, at pressures of 4–20 MPa, and gasification processes at >500 °C. The processes are considered to offer high throughputs and increased energy and separation efficiencies [62]. Hydrothermal liquefactions typically result in oils which have a low oxygen content (10%–20%) relative to those produced by fast pyrolysis, and have high energy efficiency (by avoiding water phase change) and operate at lower temperatures. However, hydrothermal liquefactions use a longer residence time (10–60 min) [63]. 3.1.2 Chemistry involved in thermo-chemical conversion The initial pyrolysis of biomass into oil, gas and char are classed as “primary reactions”. It is possible for auto-catalytic “secondary reactions” to take place in the vapor phase, or between the vapor and solid phases, which result in the increased generation of gases. These secondary reactions include cracking and the water–gas shift reaction. Cracking is the breaking-down of molecules into lighter, more volatile saturated/unsaturated compounds. The reactions can be avoided by limiting the maximum temperature used (<700 °C), minimizing the residence time of the vapor phase and by rapid separation of char [53]. The pyrolysis of cellulose is most widely understood, and several major pathways are considered to operate under different temperature regimes. At the lowest temperatures, over long residence times, partial depolymerization results in the formation of shorter chains (~200 units) [47]. At relatively low temperatures and slow rates of heating, dehydration reactions lead primarily to the formation of water and other gases. The corresponding production of unsaturated (C=C, C=O) polymers ultimately forms char. Regardless of particle size, low temperatures result in the formation of char by this dehydration process [64]. Above ~300 °C, the formation of an “active” form of cellulose during pyrolysis is commonly invoked, having a reduced degree of polymerization. This is considered as an initiation step. The exact nature of this intermediate species is somewhat controversial, and is a general term used among different types of processes [65,66]. From “active cellulose”, two further major pathways compete at higher temperatures as shown in Fig. 3(b) [50,53,64]. More extensive sequential depolymerization reactions dominate in the temperature range ~300–400 °C, resulting primarily in the formation of levoglucosan (1, 6-anhydro-beta-d-glucopyranose), a dehydrated analogue of glucose, and other primary anhydrosugars and oligosaccharides [67]. Yields of up to around 60 wt% levoglucosan have been reported [59]. These volatile transglycosylation products are formed by chain-end depolymerization reactions, involving breaking of glycosidic bonds. At higher temperatures, fragmentation of cellulose into hydroxyacetaldehyde, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural and other light C2-C4 oxygenates (carbonyls, acids and alcohols) dominates, with an optimum temperature of ~600 °C [68]. The fragmentation processes involve opening and reforming of the pyranoid rings, which requires higher activation energies than for the depolymerization steps [69]. β-scission reactions of the polymer chains, followed by further molecular and radical reactions, form further degradation products. The initiation of radical pathways are considered to be facilitated by the presence of oxygen or organic impurities in the biomass [70]. With longer times, levoglucosan can undergo secondary pyrolysis reactions, or repolymerizations. Above 600 °C secondary cracking reactions dominate, such that oil and char products tend towards gaseous decomposition products. Above 700 °C, the carbon-content of the pyrolysis oil increases due to decarboxylation and dehydration reactions [50]. Due to the range of reactions occurring at different temperatures, flash pyrolysis reactions designed for high yields of pyrolysis oil rely on fast heating rates to minimize the number of reactions taking place at temperatures below the desired reaction temperature. In addition to temperature, the competition between depolymerization and fragmentation routes can be affected by e.g. the presence of alkaline earth metals in the biomass feedstock. These have been found to catalyse the cellulose fragmentation reactions by coordinating to the hydroxyl groups, destabilizing the glucose rings. This reduces the yields of levoglucosan produced and increases the complexity of the product mixtures [59]. Hemicelluloses can be considered to pyrolyze through similar routes to cellulose: At low temperatures, dehydration is favored forming water, gases, char, and further acids and anhydrides; at higher temperatures, depolymerization again forms levoglucosan and other anhydrosugars, alongside levoglucosene (the dehydration product of levoglucosan), furans and other volatile organics. Whilst lignin follows the same pattern of dehydration at lower temperatures and depolymerization at higher temperatures, its greater thermal stability relative to cellulose and hemicelluloses means that its dehydration reactions (ultimately generating char) play a more significant role [53]. The reactions occurring during gasification can be broadly divided into heterogeneous (those occurring between feedstock and gases) and homogeneous reactions (those occurring between the gaseous products). The heterogeneous reactions include full, and partial, oxidation producing CO2 and CO; reactions with steam to form CO, CO2 and H2; the Boudard reaction (C + CO2 → CO); and reaction with hydrogen to form methane. The homogeneous reactions include oxidation of H2, CO and CH4 (to CO2 + H2O), the water–gas shift reaction, and steam-methane reforming (CH4 + H2O → CO + 3H2). Whilst the reactions include both exothermic and endothermic processes, the process is mostly exothermic overall because of the energy released during CO2 formation [69]. 3.2 Biological conversion and the chemistry Biological conversion is another important pathway for producing fuels from lignocellulosic biomass. According to the state of fuels, the biological conversion can be generally classified in two types. One is for gaseous fuels production, and the other is for liquid fuels production. Biomethane and biohydrogen are two major gaseous fuels. Bio-alcohols such as bioethanol and biobutanol are typical liquid fuels generated via bioconversion. 3.2.1 Biological conversion for gaseous fuels production 3.2.1.1 Biomethane Biomethane is a highly promising biofuel that can be utilized as a transport fuel or injected in the natural gas grid [71]. It can be produced from almost all types of biomass, including wet biomass achieving waste treatment simultaneously with producing energy [72]. Nowadays, biomethane production as a cost-effective method to produce energy from lignocellulosic biomass has been implemented all around the world [73]. Table 1 lists some recent research on biomethane production from lignocellulosic biomass. Biomethane production varies with sources of lignocellulosic biomass but generally the yield is less than 330 mL CH4 /g volatile solids (VS). Anaerobic digestion is a main biological technology to produce bio-methane from lignocellulosic biomass that can occur naturally. It can be divided into four key stages: hydrolysis, acidogenesis, acetogenesis and methanogenesis. The first stage is the hydrolysis of complex carbohydrates (cellulose and hemicellulose) to yield monosaccharides such as glucose, xylose and galactose [79] . This step follows first-order kinetics and is generally considered as the rate-limiting step in early stage anaerobic digestion of lignocellulosic biomass, primarily due to existence of the plant cell wall that protects the structural carbohydrates from microbial and enzymatic degradation [80]. Because of the recalcitrance of lignocellulosic biomass to biodegradation, it is necessary to apply pretreatment to break the complex structure of the biomass prior to anaerobic digestion to improve the enzymatic hydrolysis efficiency. Various pretreatment methods can be employed including thermal, physical, chemical, physio-chemical and biological pretreatments [81], among which physical pretreatment to reduce the particle size is the cheapest and the most commonly used method for biomethane production. Hydrolysis is followed by the acidogenesis step. Eqs. (1)–(3) represent three typical acidogenesis reactions of glucose. In this stage, acidogenic bacteria (e.g. Streptococcus, Lactobacillus, Bacillus, Escherichia coli, Salmonella) convert the monosaccharides generated from the hydrolysis stage to a mixture of short chain volatile fatty acids, carbon dioxide and alcohols [82,83]. The acidogenesis reaction is much faster than hydrolysis because it occurs in the liquid phase. Meanwhile, formation of fatty acids easily leads to a drop in pH and makes the conditions beneficial for those bacteria preferring a slightly acidic environment with a pH of 4.5 to 5.5. (1) C 6 H 12 O 6 → 2CH 3 CH 2 OH + 2CO 2 (2) C 6 H 12 O 6 + 2H 2 → 2CH 3 CH 2 COOH + 2H 2 O (3) C 6 H 12 O 6 → 3CH 3 COOH The third stage is acetogenesis as shown in Eqs. (4)–(6). In this stage, fatty acids and alcohols are further converted to acetate, hydrogen and carbon dioxide by acetogenic bacteria [84]. Ethanol cannot be directly converted to methane and carbon dioxide but is initially transformed to acetate. Hydrogen formed in this step is considered as an inhibitory product owing to its inhibiting effect on the metabolism of acetogenic bacteria [85]. This reaction only proceeds in conditions with low hydrogen partial pressure which allows the conversion thermodynamically. (4) H 3 CH 2 COO - + 3H 2 O → CH 3 COO - + H + + HCO 3 - + 3H 2 (5) C 6 H 12 O 6 + 2H 2 O → 2CH 3 COOH + 4H 2 + 2CO 2 (6) CH 3 CH 2 OH + 2H 2 O → CH 3 COO - + 2H 2 + H + The last stage is methanogensis in which methane is generated by methanogenic microorganisms belonging to Archae. For methanogen, H2/CO2, formate, acetate and methylated C1 compounds (e.g. ethanol) can be used as carbon sources and energy for its growth. The most common metabolic pathway (Eq. (7)) is converting carbon dioxide and hydrogen using hydrogenotrophic archaea to produce methane. Converting acetate (acetic acid) to methane and carbon dioxide by acetotrophic archaea (Eq. (8)) is another important pathway. Additionally, methanol can be also used as substrate to produce methane. Normally, methanogensis is the rate-limiting step in the late stage of anaerobic digestion of biomass because methanogenic bacteria are growing slower than acidogenic bacteria and are sensitive to changes [86] . (7) CO 2 + 4 H 2 → CH 4 + 2 H 2 O (8) CH 3 COOH → CH 4 + CO 2 Though anaerobic digestion can be thought to occur in these four stages, all processes occur simultaneously and synergistically [85]. 3.2.1.2 Biohydrogen Hydrogen is a potential alternative to fossil fuels due to its unique characteristics such as a high gravimetric-based energy content and an absence of greenhouse gas release after combustion or oxidation [87]. It can be mixed with natural gas for use or used in fuel cells to directly produce energy [88]. Bio-hydrogen generally refers to the hydrogen produced via bioconversion. Recently, bioconversion of lignocellulosic biomass to produce bio-hydrogen has been considered as an alluring technology to generate green and clean fuel [89]. Dark fermentation and photo fermentation are two major biological methods for biohydrogen production from lignocellulosic biomass [90]. Dark fermentation is conducted by obligate or facultative anaerobic bacteria in the absence of light to convert organic compounds such as sugars to yield bio-hydrogen and side products such as acetic acid and alcohols [89,91]. Eqs. (9)–(11) represent the dark-fermentative hydrogen production from glucose. Generally, the production of acetic acid and butyric acid is beneficial for bio-hydrogen production. However, propionic acid consumes bio-hydrogen and achieves a low yield [92]. A wide range of lignocellulosic biomass sources have been studied for biohydrogen production as shown in Table 2 . Prior to dark fermentation, lignocellulosic biomass also needs pretreatment to break the complex structure and increase the monomeric sugars content needed by hydrogen-producing microorganisms [92]. The biohydrogen yield is affected by several factors including the source of lignocellulosic biomass, source of inoculum, operating conditions (e.g. temperature, pH, hydraulic retention time, hydrogen partial pressure) and fermentation end-products. (9) C 6 H 12 O 6 + 2H 2 O → 2CH 3 COOH + 2CO 2 + 4H 2 (10) C 6 H 12 O 6 → CH 3 CH 2 CH 2 COOH + 2CO 2 + 2H 2 (11) C 6 H 12 O 6 + 2H 2 → 2CH 3 CH 2 COOH + 2H 2 O Photo-fermentation is another important biological way to produce bio-hydrogen from lignocellulosic biomass. Being different from dark-fermentation, photo-fermentation needs to be carried out in the presence of light by photosynthetic microorganisms [100]. Jiang et al. studied the photo-fermentative hydrogen production from corn stalk pith with a photosynthetic consortium [101]. The corn stalk pith was firstly enzymatically hydrolyzed, and then the hydrolysate was used as substrate to produce hydrogen. The maximum hydrogen yield (2.61 mol H2/mol glucose) is higher or comparable to those reported in literatures. In single stage dark fermentation, the H2 production is not efficient because only part of the substrate can be converted to hydrogen [102]. The effluents from dark fermentation mainly consist of volatile fatty acids such as acetic acid and butyric acid, which can be used as substrate of photo fermentation to produce hydrogen. Thus, two-stage dark-photo fermentation is much more beneficial than single dark or photo fermentation. In this system, two fermentation processes are conducted in different reactors and the organic acids generated from dark-fermentation can be converted to hydrogen by photo-fermentation [102]. Several types of lignocellulosic biomass have been studied to produce hydrogen using two-stage fermentation [103]. 3.2.2 Biological conversion for liquid fuels production 3.2.2.1 Bioethanol Bioethanol produced from renewable sources is one of the most potential and eco-friendly alternatives to fossil fuels [104]. Production of bioethanol from lignocellulosic biomass has received an increasing interest owing to the relatively low cost, high abundance and renewability of the feedstock. There are two main routes to produce ethanol from lignocellulosic biomass: thermo-chemical and biological. Compared to thermo-chemical method, biological conversion is a common method to produce ethanol owing to its high efficiency and selectivity of conversion. Biological conversion of lignocellulosic biomass to ethanol generally includes three key steps: pretreatment, enzymatic hydrolysis and fermentation of sugars (Fig. 4 ) [105]. After pretreatment, the pretreated cellulose-rich solid is used as substrate to yield monomeric sugars by enzymes. During enzymatic hydrolysis, cellulose is mainly hydrolyzed by cellulase to glucose and hemicelluloses are converted to several soluble monomeric sugars such as xylose, glucose, galactose as shown in Eqs. (12)–(13). The maximum theoretical yield of glucose and xylose is 1.111 g and 1.136 g per g of glucan and xylan, respectively. (12) ( C 6 H 10 O 5 ) n + n H 2 O → n C 6 H 12 O 6 (13) ( C 5 H 8 O 4 ) n + n H 2 O → n C 5 H 10 O 5 The last step is the fermentation of sugar-rich hydrolysates obtained from both pretreatment and enzymatic hydrolysis process using fermentation organisms. Eqs. (14) and (15) represent the anaerobic fermentation reactions of glucose and xylose, and Eqs. (16) and (17) represent the anaerobic fermentation reactions of cellobiose and xylobiose. The theoretical yield of ethanol from monomeric sugars is 0.51 g ethanol/g sugar, while that from disaccharides is 0.540 g ethanol g−1 disaccharides [104]. (14) C 6 H 12 O 6 → 2 CH 3 CH 2 OH + 2 CO 2 (15) 3 C 5 H 10 O 5 → 5 CH 3 CH 2 OH + 5 CO 2 (16) C 12 H 22 O 11 + H 2 O → 5 CH 3 CH 2 OH + 5 CO 2 (17) 3 C 10 H 18 O 9 + 3 H 2 O → 10 CH 3 CH 2 OH + 10 CO 2 The fermentation organisms mainly include yeast (e.g. Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Pichia stipites) and bacteria (e.g. Zymomonas mobilis, Clostridium thermocellum). Yeast S. cerevisiae is a robust strain, which can give high ethanol yields and shows high tolerance to ethanol and lignocellulose-derived inhibitors [106]. However, the hydrolysates are a mixture of hexoses (mainly glucose) and pentoses (mainly xylose) and most of the wild-type strains of S. cerevisiae do not utilize pentoses [106]. In order to increase the range of consumed sugars and improve the ethanol yield, it is necessary to obtain microorganisms capable of fermenting hexoses and pentoses. This problem can be addressed using genetic modification methods, which mainly include two methods: introduction of additional pentose metabolic pathways into conventional strains and mutagenesis [107]. Table 3 lists some recently reported studies of bioethanol fermentation from lignocellulosic biomass using different microorganisms. During ethanol fermentation, many factors such as temperature, pH, time, agitation rate, sugar concentration, inoculum concentration and concentration of inhibitors show influence on ethanol yield [120]. The temperature affects the growth rate of microorganisms directly, thus the optimal temperature greatly depends on the ideal temperature for yeasts. The pH of most fermenting medium is in the range of 4.5–5.5. The fermentation process is commonly conducted for 24 h to 72 h with an agitation rate at 120 and 150 rpm. 3.2.2.2 Biobutanol Biobutanol is another important liquid fuel from lignocellulosic biomass, which can be used as biofuel or fuel additive. It has several advantages over ethanol such as lower volatility, higher energy content, energy density, and liquid heat capacity [121]. Microbial fermentation is superior to chemical methods for biobutanol production, mainly because this process is much more environment-friendly. The microbial fermentation for biobutanol production generally refers to Acetone-butanol-ethanol (ABE) fermentation, which is widely used for butanol production from lignocellulosic biomass [122–124]. This process generally includes two steps: firstly, sugars are consumed to produce organic acids (acetic acid, butyric acid) together with cell growth in the acidogenic phase, leading to a drop in pH; then, the cell growth is halted and the organic acids formed are converted to yield solvents (acetone, butanol and ethanol) in the solventogenic phase [125]. Butanol can be produced from a wide range of lignocellulosic biomass (e.g. switchgrass, corn stover, wheat straw) by several solventogenic clostridia such as Clostridium acetobutylicum, Clostridium beijerinckii and Clostridium tyrobutyricum. Most Clostridia strains can use both hexoses and pentoses to produce bio-butanol. In general, the mass portion of acetone, butanol and ethanol is 3:6:1 [126]. However, because of the potential oversupply of acetone, the traditional ABE fermentation has been considered as economically risky. Decreasing or eliminating acetone production by metabolic engineering is beneficial for improving the ratio and yield of butanol [127]. Jiang et al. disrupted acetoacetate decarboxylase gene (adc) in Clostridium acetobutylicum EA 2018 using Targetron technology in order to reduce acetone production [128]. The butanol ratio in solvent increased from 70% to 85%, and the acetone production decreased from 2.83 g L−1 to 0.21 g L−1. To summarize, biological conversion of lignocellulosic biomass represents a promising way to produce liquid biofuels such as ethanol and butanol, which has almost reached commercialization. However, efforts still need to be made in order to overcome the bottle-necks involving the pretreatment to deconstruct cell wall structure, cellulase production for efficient and inexpensive release of fermentable sugars, utilization of pentose, product recovery with low energy consumption as well as process integration to improve the economic feasibility. 4 Lignocellulosic biomass as a fuel for power generation with fuel cell technologies Fuel cell technology attracts great interest because of its clean, efficient and flexible characteristics and has been regarded as the next generation of power generation technology. Lignocellulosic biomass can be used as a fuel indirectly or directly to different fuel cells. A range of fuel cell technologies have been developed to generate electricity with lignocellulose or its derived products as fuels. The solid oxide fuel cell is capable of using lignocellulose-derived flammable gas to generate electricity. The biochar can be utilized in direct carbon fuel cells. The microbial fuel cell is able to convert biomass-derived compounds, such as sugars, acetic acid, etc., into electricity under mild conditions. Mediated fuel cells can directly utilize untreated biomass to generate electricity under the assistance of electron carriers. 4.1 Solid oxide fuel cell Solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) is an all-solid-state fuel cell technology with comprehensive application prospects. Compared to fuel cells using liquid electrolytes, SOFC has many advantages such as no corrosion, no electrolyte leakage, and a stable structure. The operation temperature of SOFC is relatively high (usually >600 °C) which enables SOFC technology to achieve high energy conversion efficiency (>80%) and fuel universality without a noble metal catalyst [129]. Typically, the SOFC consists of two porous electrode layers where electrochemical reactions occur and a dense solid within the cell [130]. During operation, gaseous fuel containing H2, CO and CH4 enters the anode chamber and participates in the electrochemical reaction in the three phase boundary (TPB, the three phase boundary is the contact interfaces of the solid electron phase, solid ionic phase and fuel phase). Electrons are then transferred to the cathode via an external circuit and then combine with O2 to form O2− ions in the cathode. The dense electrolyte can transfer O2– formed in the cathode to the anode and O2– participates in the electrochemical oxidation of fuel. The electrochemical reaction equation of H2 fueled SOFC can be expressed as: (18) Anode : H 2 + O 2 - - 2 e - → H 2 O (19) Cathode : O 2 + 4 e - → 2 O 2 - The performance of SOFCs is influenced by a series of factors such as electrolyte type, electrode material, and fuel composition [131]. The major difference between SOFC and other fuel cells is the use of solid electrolytes. Suitable electrolyte materials should possess high ionic conductivity to transport O2− ion accelerated as well as low electronic conductivity to avoid electric leakage [132]. 8 mol% yttrium stabilized zirconia (YSZ) is a frequently-used electrolyte with a long history which can rapidly transfer O2− ions when the operation temperature is above 650 °C [133]. Gd doped CeO2 (GDC) and Sm doped CeO2 (SDC) can be utilized as electrolytes in low-temperature SOFC systems because of its excellent ion conductivity under 650 °C [134]. Moreover, divalent cation doped LaGaO3 materials like La0.9Sr0.1Ga0.8Mg0.2O2.85 (LSGM) [135] are commonly used electrolytes as well because they have relatively good ion conductivity over a wide temperature range. At present, a high operation temperature is needed for SOFC to maintain the high ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. However, such a high temperature operating environment puts forward higher requirements for battery materials and for temperature control management. Hence, one of the research hotspots of SOFC is to improve the morphology and structure of the electrolyte by adjusting the composition of the electrolyte so as to build a low-temperature high-performance electrolyte [134]. Electrodes of SOFC are usually porous ceramics that possess high electronic conductivity to reduce polarization resistance as well as high ionic conductivity to increase TPB areas [136]. At the same time, the porous structure of the electrode reduces transport resistance of the carrier gas. Ni/GDC, Ni/YSZ, Ni/SDC are commonly used anodes of SOFC. Metal doping improves the electronic conductivity of the anode and can provide more active sites [137]. Mixed ionic-electronic conductors like perovskite materials or double perovskite [138] materials also can be invoked as the anode for SOFC. The utilization of mixed ionic-electronic conductors expands the typical TPB to the fuel/anode double phase boundary. Perovskite materials like Sr doped LaMnO3 (LSM) and Sr/Fe doped LaCoO3 (LSCF) can be used as cathodes for SOFC [139]. LSM is a conventional cathode material with excellent chemical stability, and its thermal expansion performance matches the YSZ electrolyte, which is conducive to the improvement of mechanical properties [140] . The fuel for SOFC comes from a wide range of sources by a variety of ways. H2 is an ideal fuel for SOFC with the highest fuel utilization efficiency [141]. CO can also be used as fuel, however, the electrochemical oxidation kinetics of CO fuel is lower than H2, since CO has a larger molecular weight and lower diffusion rate [142]. Methane is a promising fuel for SOFC as well. Methane can directly undergo electrochemical oxidation. It is also believed that methane is first reformed in-situ to CO and H2 and then participates in the electrochemical reaction [137]. Typical SOFC fuel such as hydrogen, CO and methane can be produced from biomass by biochemical or thermochemical processes. There are plenty of reports on SOFC fueled with biomass derived fuel gases such as bio-methane and bio-hydrogen produced by anaerobic digestion of biomass and syngas obtained from gasification as reviewed in the aforementioned section. Table 4 lists the components and performance of some bio-gas or syngas-fueled SOFC systems reported in recent years. The fuel composition has significant effects on SOFC performance. Among the components of biomass gas, H2 is relatively easy to electrochemically oxidize, followed by CO and methane is the worst. Numerous approaches have been developed to improve methane utilization efficiency. For example, methane-rich bio-gas can be converted to H2 and CO through reform processes like the steam reforming process, dry reforming process or partial oxidation reforming process using a separate reform device in front of SOFC [152]. The direct internal reforming process of SOFC can also be realized by mixing oxygen, water and other reforming agents into the fuel gas [154]. Bio-gas is rich in CO2, which reduces the calorific value, but also creates conditions for direct internal dry reforming of methane. Methane can be effectively reformed into hydrogen and CO in situ with catalysis of the catalyst layer loaded on the anode. Proton conducting materials [148], perovskites [146], transition metals [154] and transition metal oxides [156] are selected to catalyze the direct inner dry reform process. In addition, adding a certain amount of N2 into the fuel gas can obviously improve the stability of the SOFC [149] . Compared to purified fuel gas, biomass-derived gas contains impurities such as coke, siloxane, H2S, NH3, HCl, NOx and SOx which reduce the cell performance [151]. Moreover, carbon deposition occurs because of methane decomposition and the boudouard reaction when biomass derived gas is used as fuel [143]. An effective strategy to avoid impurity toxicity and carbon deposition is to improve the purity and hydrogen content of biomass gas through extra purification processes and reforming processes. The development of SOFC anode materials that are in line with fuel gas and are resistant to sulfur and carbon deposition is a more effective solution strategy and has advantages in system integration and thermal management. Perovskite anodes have been reported to have good carbon and sulfur resistance [147]. Introducing perovskite-type oxides [142] and metal nanoparticle catalysts [130] into the Ni/YSZ anode can also significantly reduce the formation of carbon in the surface area of anode Ni and the adsorption of sulphur. In addition, a CeO2 anode doped by a transition metal also has better sulfur resistance and carbon deposition resistance [135]. In addition, the continuous process of coupling the biomass gas production process with the SOFC electricity production can further improve the energy efficiency of the system [156], which has obvious advantages in social economy and environment and has a great prospect for application. 4.2 Direct carbon fuel cell The direct carbon fuel cell (DCFC) is a high-temperature (usually>500 °C) fuel cell technology that can directly convert the chemical energy in solid carbon fuel into electricity. The theoretical thermodynamics efficiency is slightly larger than 100% and the efficiency is also larger than 80% in practical use [157]. Hence, compared to the current coal-burning power plant, the direct carbon fuel cell has a lower CO2 emission at the same amount of electricity generation. Being similar to other kinds of fuel cells, the DCFC consists of a cathode, an anode and electrolytes. The separating membrane is unnecessary for some DCFCs. Based on the difference of electrolyte, DCFC can be divided in to three types: molten hydroxide fuel cell (MHFC), molten carbonate fuel cell (MCFC) and solid oxide direct carbon fuel cell (SO-DCFC). The electrolyte difference directly results in the difference in the cell structure, electrode materials and electrochemical reaction of these DCFC technologies. LiOH, NaOH, KOH, and their mixture are used as the electrolyte for MHFC. The operation temperature of MHFC is between 500 °C–650 °C, which is lower than that of MCFC and SO-DCFC. The molten hydroxide electrolyte has a relatively high electrical conductivity and faster electrochemical oxidation kinetics can be obtained under relatively low operating temperatures. MHFC usually uses a carbon rod as anode and fuel, while the metal container (usually Ni2Fe alloy) that contains electrolytes is the cathode (Fig. 5 (a)). Ceramics (porous zirconia) or anti-corrosion porous metal Ni can be the separator to separate the anode and cathode in the dual-chamber DHFC system to avoid the voltage loss caused by direct contact of fuel and oxygen [158]. Moreover, when an extra porous metal material is used as the anode current collector, carbon powder can also be used as a fuel [159]. The electrode reactions of MHFC system are shown below: (20) Anode : C + 4 OH - → 2 H 2 O + CO 2 + 4 e - (21) Cathode : O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - → 4 OH - One of the technical difficulties of MHFC is the formation of CO3 2−, which results in electrolyte instability and electrode corrosion. It has been found that adding H2O or oxides like SiO2 and MgO can reduce the formation of CO3 2− and improve the cell stability [160]. MCFC is the most promising DCFC technology for commercial applications. Li2CO3, Na2CO3, K2CO3 and their mixture are used as the electrolyte for MCFC. The operation temperature of MCFC is between 600 to 800 °C which is higher than that of MHFC but lower than that of SO-DCFC [161]. The electrical conductivity of the carbonate electrolyte is relatively lower than that hydroxide; however, the tolerance to CO2 has been significantly improved by using the carbonate electrolyte. Either carbon powders or carbon rod can serve as fuel for MCFC. MCFC usually uses metal as electrodes. A porous LiAlO2 diaphragm can be utilized to reduce cathodic corrosion, and the carbonate is transferred from the cathode to the anode via the diaphragm channel [162] (Fig. 5(b)). The electrode reactions of MCFC are shown below: (22) A n o d e C + 2 CO 3 2 - → 3 CO 2 + 4 e - (23) Cathode : O 2 + 2 CO 2 + 4 e - → 2 CO 3 2 - Boudouard reaction is inevitable while the MCFC is running. Hence another electrochemical oxidation pathway of carbon is the formation of CO through boudouard reaction and then electrochemical oxidation [161]. The main technical difficulty of MCFC is the development of new electrode materials for corrosion resistance at high temperatures. Moreover, the optimization of electrolyte components is also the focus of the research. The operating temperature of MCFC can be significantly reduced by setting the multi-carbonate electrolyte. Being analogous to SOFC, the SO-DCFC utilizes solid oxygen ion conductors like YSZ, GDC and SDC as electrolytes. SO-DCFC runs at 800 °C–1000 °C since the solid electrolytes have better ionic conductivity at higher temperatures [161]. In SO-DCFC, the electrochemical oxidation of solid carbon occurs in three phase boundary, namely the contact interfaces of the solid electron phase, solid ionic phase and fuel phase. The SO-DCFC can be divided into direct contact type (Fig. 5(c)) and indirect contact type (Fig. 5(d)) based on whether the carbon fuel is in contact with the anode. For the direct contact SO-DCFC, the fuel phase is solid carbon, which results in poor contact with the solid electron phase and solid ionic phase [163]. At present, various methods have been developed to expand the three-phase boundary of SO-DCFC, such as using a fluidized bed to continuously flow fuel to the anode and electrolyte interface [164], or mixing ionic conductors into the fuel to expand the three-phase interface to the entire anode area [165]. The direct electrochemical oxidation reactions of carbon fuels are shown below: (24) Anode : C + 2 O 2 - → CO 2 + 4 e - (25) Cathode : O 2 + 4 e - → 2 O 2 - The carbon fuel of indirect contact SO-DCFC is physically separated from the anode. At high temperature, Boudouard reaction occurs and the carbon fuel is reformed to CO and then electrochemical oxidation of CO occurs at the anode: Anode: (26) C + CO 2 → 2 CO (27) CO + O 2 - → CO 2 + 2 e - The gasification catalysts such as Fe2O3, CaO and MgO can be loaded on the carbon fuel to expedite the Boudouard reaction [166]. In addition, the performance of SO-DCFC is further improved by mixing redox media such as molten carbonate [167] and molten metal [168] into carbon fuels. Molten carbonate (Fig. 5(e)) and molten metal (Fig. 5(f)) can transfer electrons and ions to mediate the electrochemical oxidation of fuel carbon. Anode electrochemical reactions using molten carbonate media can be described as follows: (28) CO + CO 3 2 - → 2 CO 2 + 2 e - (29) C + 2 CO 3 2 - → 3 CO 2 + 4 e - (30) CO 2 + O 2 - → CO 3 2 - Anode electrochemical reaction using molten metal media can be described as follows: (31) M + n O 2 - → MO n + 2 n e - (32) ( n 2 ) C + MO n → ( n 2 ) CO 2 + M where M represents molten metal. One of the advantages of direct carbon fuel cells over other fuel cells is the fact that they can convert solid carbon fuel directly into electricity without the extra reforming process. DCFC has a wide range of fuel sources that have relatively good matches with the current energy structure. Coal, graphite, coke and biochar can be used as fuel for DCFC. Kacprzak et al. [159] analyzed the influence of fuel types on MHFC cells. The results revealed that coal fed MHFC and biochar fed MFC have better performance than graphite or black carbon fueled MHFC. Biomass represented as lignocellulose has a wide range of sources and low price. It is an inevitable requirement for sustainable development to use biomass carbon instead of coal and other non-renewable resources for power generation by the DCFC system. Table 5 lists the components and performance of DCFC systems fueled by biochar reported in recent years. As aforementioned, biochar is a carbon-rich porous solid with high aromatization and is produced by lignocellulosic biomass at elevated temperatures under anaerobic or oxygen-deficient conditions. The carbon, oxygen and hydrogen contents of biochar are 60%–90%, 0–40% and 1%–7%, respectively [180]. Thermochemical processes like fast pyrolysis, slow pyrolysis, gasification and hydrothermal carbonization can produce biochar. The composition, structure and properties of biomass, oxygen content and preparation conditions (maximum temperature, pyrolysis time, gas flow rate and pyrolysis rate) have significant influence on the electrochemical properties of biochar [181]. The frequently-used biochar preparation method for DCFC is slow pyrolysis. It is generally believed that more biochar can be obtained by using a slow pyrolysis method. The properties of biochar are related to the pyrolysis conditions such as heating rate, pyrolysis time and gas flow rate, as reviewed in the aforementioned section. Generally, low pyrolysis temperature, slow flow rate and low heating rate result in high biochar yield. Biochar with large specific surface area can be obtained when the pyrolysis temperature is above 450 oC because of the rapid release of volatile matter. Suitable biochar for DCFCs can be obtained by regulating pyrolysis conditions. Recently, Wang et al. reported that the operation time of SO-DCFC can be significantly prolonged when bamboo biochar obtained at a higher heat treatment temperature was used, which indicates that higher temperature treatment could increase the effective carbon content in fuel [181]. Currently, a large amount of biomass-derived biochar is reported to be suitable for DCFC. The influence of biomass raw materials on the performance of DCFC is indirect. That is, the difference in the properties of biomass raw materials leads to the difference in the properties of the obtained biochar, which then affects the performance of DCFC. The properties of each biomass source have significant influence on thermal conversion processes, such as the proximate analysis (ash and moisture content), calorific value, fixed carbon, inorganic element composition, volatile components as well as percentage of lignin, cellulose and hemicelluloses. Qiu et al. [170] assessed the performance of different biochar fueled SO-DCFC. Under the same pyrolysis conditions, the bagasse biochar has a lower crystallinity and larger specific surface area compared compareed with wheat straw char and corn cob char. Hence, bagasse biochar fueled SO-DCFC obtained the highest peak-power output. However, the principle, cell structure and discharge conditions of DCFC as well as the pyrolysis conditions of biochar reported in different literature reports are quite different. Therefore, it is difficult to determine which biomass is more suitable for DCFCs. One accepted conclusion is that biochar with low crystallinity and a porous structure is more suitable for DCFC to generate electricity. The coarse surface of biochar with low crystallinity can provide more reaction sites while biochar with a porous structure possesses larger reaction areas and lower diffusion resistances. It should be noted that the properties of biochar should match with the operation principle and cell structure of DCFC. For DCFCs with fuel as the anode, their fuel requires relatively good electrical conductivity and compactness in order to reduce ohmic impedance and to enhance the anode electrochemical reaction [161]. For DCFCs with carbon powders as fuel, compared to high-crystallinity graphite, biochar is more suitable because its amorphous structure possesses more reaction sites. For DCFCs with molten electrolyte, better wettability of carbon fuel in the electrolyte showed better performance of MCFC [179]. The volatilization of volatile substances and the degradation of lignin benzene rings in the pyrolysis process make the biochar rich in pore structure and a large specific surface area that may increase the wettability of biochar [182]. Kacprzak et al. analyzed the performance of DCFCs fed with different biochars that have different pore structures and the results shows that performance significantly increased using biochar with a larger pore size as fuel [159]. Moreover, DCFC performance can be further improved using active biochar fuel. The purpose of the active process is to reduce the tar content and increase the pore sizeporess [183]. Oxygen-containing functional groups such as the carboxyl group and carbonyl group are also introduced into the surface of biochar in the active process. Water steam, CO2, acid, base and inorganic salts can be used in the biomass activation process [184]. For indirect contact SO-DCFC, biochar has microelements like K and Ca that can catalyse the Boudouard reaction and increase the CO yield. Although the content of K and Ca in biochar is quite low, their distribution is very uniform, so the catalytic performance is excellent [171]. There are only a few reports on DCFC using raw biomass directly as fuel. Lan reported a MCFC system using un-carbonized wood as fuel [175]. Li et al. used un-carbonized wood chips as fuel for HDCFC. They believe that the light chain hydrocarbons formed by pyrolysis of the wood chips in the cell are associated with the electrochemical process, and thus enhanced the cell performance [167]. In general, the differences in the sources and preparation methods of biochar lead to the differences in the crystal structure (graphitization degree), particle size, impurity content and surface functional group content, which directly affect the performance of a DCFC. At the same time, most DCFCs use an intermittent fuel supply strategy, so it is necessary to further design the cell systems to realize continuous carbon fuel supply. Moreover, relevant carbon fuel standards should be developed, and biomass carbon raw materials that are more compatible with DCFC should be actively developed. 4.3 Microbial fuel cell Microbial fuel cells convert the chemicalenergy storing in lignocellulose to electricity using microorganisms as the medium [173]. In 1911 Potter found that microbes could generate electricity by degrading organic matter, which laid the theoretical foundation for MFC [185]. Since 1980, with an in-depth understanding of the microbial electron transfer mechanism and bioelectrocatalytic mechanism, as well as the application of a variety of low-cost, highly stable electrode materials, the performance of MFC increased significantly and MFC technology has shown the prospect for application. An MFC consists of an anode, a cathode and an ion (proton) exchange membrane. As a “bridge” for the conversion of chemical energy into electricity, microbes grow in the anode chamber and convert the fuel to CO2. Microbes can extract electrons from fuel through respiration and fermentation and obtain energy for life through a multi-step electron transfer process [186]. With the help of redox media, microbes are capable of transferring electrons to the anode material, from which they are then transferred to the cathode via external circuits (Fig. 5(g)). Under the catalysis of the cathode, oxygen combines electrons from the anode and protons from the electrolyte to form water. The voltage difference between the anode and the cathode causes the electrons to move forward in a direction generating electrical energy [173]. Microorganisms can use a variety of organic fuels to generate electricity at low temperature and atmospheric pressure. Table 6 shows the performance of MFC systems fueled by lignocellulose and its derivatives reported in recent years. The performance of MFCs greatly depends on the utilization of fuels by the electricity-producing microorganisms. The cell performance and anode biofilm growth is affected by the properties of the substrates. It is difficult for microorganisms to directly degrade raw lignocellulose without pretreatment because of the recalcitrance of the lignocellulose structure. Hence, though there are some reports that raw lignocellulose like cattle manure [206] or rice bran [204] can be used as fuel, these MFCs have relatively poor performance. A pretreatment process is necessary and important in order to improve the performance of a MFC, since the pretreatment procedure destroys the structure of lignocellulose and releases a variety of fermentable products [207]. Miran et al. compared the discharge performance of MFC fueled by dried orange peel powder with that fueled by orange peel juice, and the results shows that the latter had a better discharge performance [208]. Takeuchi et al. analyzed the relationship between the degree of cellulose degradation and electricity generation, and found that the electric current built up as the degradation of cellulose increased [209]. In a rice bran fed MFC system, the total electron transfer increased by ~26% when rice bran pretreated by hydrodynamic cavitation was fueled [204]. Many kinds of fermentable products such as monosaccharides and acetic acid can be obtained from pretreated lignocellulose. Glucose can be obtained from cellulose hydrolysis and hexose, pentose, uronic acid, acetic acid and other fermentable substances can be produced from hemicellulose hydrolysis. These fermentable substances can be used as the only carbon sources in MFCs. Catal et al. studied the performances of MFCs fed by 12 monosaccharides and the results show that D-mannose resulted in the lowest maximum power density, whereas D-glucuronic acid generated the highest one [187]. Glucose is the main energy source, and microorganisms have developed multiple metabolic pathways to utilize glucose. Hence, many MFCs utilize glucose as a fuel in the literature. It is important to note that glucose is relatively easy to ferment, thus a variety of metabolic pathways that do not generate electricity exist in microorganisms to consume glucose which results in a low Coulombic efficiency in glucose fed MFC [210]. Phenol compounds degraded from lignin are considered to be the inhibitor, however, some microorganisms are able to use phenolic compounds to produce electricity. For example, small molecule species obtained from lignin using a photocatalytic degradation process can be used as fuel in MFCs [200]. Nevertheless, high fuel concentrations inhibit the growth of microorganisms and reduce the performance of MFCs [211]. The presence of phenolic compounds in fuel also acts as electron transfer media and improve the electron transport rate of microorganisms to the anode. A significant increase of the maximum power density was observed in glucose fed MFCs when humic acid was added [212]. Moreover, lignocellulose derivatives such as acetate [196] and sugar degradation products like furfural [199] can also be used as fuel to generate electricity in MFC systems. Acetate is a simple substrate obtained from ethanol, glucose or complex organic matter through acidogenesis [210]. Acetate has been declared to be a better substrate for electricity generation followed by saccharides. MFC fed by lignin drivers have the poorest performance. Furthermore, biomass hydrolysates can be directly used in MFCs to generate electricity [202]. However, fermentation inhibitors are produced during the hydrolysis process which reduces the performance of MFCs. A variety of electricity-producing microorganisms have been reported for use in MFCs. Microorganisms can be obtained from soil [204], domestic wastewater [201], anaerobic or aerobic sludge [202] and attached to the anode to form electroactive biofilms. Electrons from the fuels can be directly transferred to the anode through cytochrome or conductive pilis on the microorganisms’ cell membranes [213]. Naturally occurring or artificially added redox electron carriers such as methylene blue and quinones can also be used to indirectly transfer electrons from microorganisms to the anode [191]. The proper design of microbial communities is an effective engineering strategy to enhance the performance of MFCs. Compared to a single microorganism system, hybrid systems can metabolize more fuel and optimize the electron transport pathway [214]. The system function is improved by the overall division of labor among multiple species in the microbiome. Each species in the microbiome is designed to perform the job at which it excels. For example, cellulose hydrolysis and electricity generation processes can be performed simultaneously through the synergistic action between different species [197]. Recently, genetic engineering technology has been utilized to optimize the metabolic pathway of electricity-producing microorganisms and to improve the utilization efficiency of fuel. Ojima et al. optimized the electrical production performance of Escherichia coli possessing multiple metabolic centers using gene knockout technology, and achieved P max of 0.27 mW/cm2 using glucose as fuel [189]. The anode material should have good conductivity, but also good bacterial adhesion. Surface properties of anode materials such as roughness, porosity and surface wettability affect the formation of biofilm and subsequent power output.
