Metal materials (stainless steel) and carbon materials (carbon clothes, carbon rod, carbon brush, graphite plate) are conventional electrodes. In recent years, the development of nanomaterials has greatly expanded the selection space of anode materials. Compared with traditional carbon electrodes, nano carbon materials like carbon nanofibers and carbon nanotubes have a larger surface area, higher electrochemical catalytic activity and stronger mechanical properties, which have greater application potential [203]. However, these novel anode materials are too expensive to be of use for large scale application. The introduction of different functional groups in the surfaces of the anode is an effective strategy to enhance affinity between anode and microorganism [215]. Moreover, biofilm growth and electron transport on the anode can be significantly improved by using a hydrophilic anode binder instead of a non-hydrophilic PDFE binder [192]. Biochar has also been utilized for MFC electrodes, which are as active as graphite. The use of biochar can reduce the costs and carbon footprints of MFC [216]. Electrons from biomass fuels are eventually received by oxygen in most MFC systems. O2 is considered an ideal electron receiver due to its ubiquity, inexhaustibility and high redox potential for MFC. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is considered to be the rate-limiting reaction in MFCs. Hence, catalysts are essential in order to boost the poor kinetics of ORR. In neutral conditions, Pt-based catalysts can catalyze four electron ORR reactions efficiently, while by-products produced by two electron ORR pathways are relatively rare [217]. However, the high cost of Pt-based catalysts greatly limits their large-scale application. MFC systems based on low-price ORR catalysts have been reported in recent years: Fe-C-N [194], Co-P [196] and activated carbon [195]. Moreover, high potential redox medias like K3[Fe(CN)6] [188], KMnO4 [144], H2O2 [218] can also be utilized as a final electron receiver. These species have faster reduction kinetics and greater solubility than oxygen, hence the MFC performance can be improved. Nevertheless, cost and regeneration properties need to be considered when using these non-oxygen electron receivers in an industrial application. The optimization of the operation conditions is very important for the growth of electric microorganisms in the anode chamber. The fuel concentration and fuel/microorganisms ratio can be optimized using response surface methodology [191]. The introduction of a buffer solution promotes the metabolic activities of microorganisms and compensates for the slow proton transport speed, thus improving the cathode reaction [219]. At present, the peak output power of MFCs is still less than 1 mW/cm2. Such a low power density makes it difficult for MFCs to be used on a large scale as a technology focusing on generating electricity. In contrast, the MFC system can be used as an energy recovery technology to realize self-sustainable or even positive recovery for energy in wastewater treatment, soil remediation seawater desalination, etc., which still makes great sense. 4.4 Mediated fuel cell Being similar to the redox flow cell, the mediated fuel cell (MEDFC) consists of an electric stack and two electrolyte tanks. Two kinds of active species or electron carriers with different electrode potentials are stored in electrolyte tanks (Fig. 5(h)) [173]. Specifically, the electron carriers with lower potentials are stored in the anode tank while the electron carriers with higher potentials are stored in the cathode tank. The stack is composed of carbon electrodes and ion exchange membranes. Electrons are transferred from the negative electrode to the positive electrode by an external circuit, and protons in the electrolyte are transferred from the positive electrolyte to the negative electrolyte through the ion exchange membrane [220]. The “charging” process of the mediated fuel cell is quite different from the redox flow cell. Regeneration of discharged electron carriers occurs in the tanks under mild conditions (usually 80 °C–100 °C or at room temperature with illumination). Specifically, the oxidized form of anode electron carriers is able to oxidize fuels to regenerate the reduced form while the reduced form of cathode electron carriers is oxidized by O2 to regenerate the oxidized form. Hence the mediated fuel cell is not an energy storage system but an energy generation system. Continuous addition of fuel in the anode chamber and supply of oxygen in the cathode chamber will ensure a steady electricity output of MEDFC. The charge and discharge process of MEDFC can be expressed by the following equation [174]: Charging process: (33) Anode r e a c t o r : Ec 1 , O + fuel → Ec 1 , R + fuel ox (34) Cathode r e a c t o r : Ec 2 , R + O 2 → H 2 O + Ec 2 , O Discharging process: Anode c h a m b e r : Ec 1 , R - e - → Ec 1 , O (36) Cathode c h a m b e r : Ec 2 , O + e - → Ec 2 , R Early researches of MEDFC usually used hydrogen as fuel. Non-gas fuels have advantages in storage, transportation and distribution compared to hydrogen fuel. Thanks to the unique “electron carrier” design in MEDFC, fuel with complex structures such as cellulose and lignin can be directly used in MEDFC system without extra pretreatment. Currently, MEDFC can convert various kinds of biomass such as glucose, starch, cellulose, lignin, polyol, low grade coal and lignocellulose raw materials into electric energy, and the power density has already come close to that of the direct methanol cell [221]. The two phase reaction in MEDFC has a relatively low masstransferresistance compared to the gas-liquid-solid three phase reaction in PEMFC. Besides, the MEDFC system decouples the ORR reaction and discharging process, which benefits the optimization of the ORR reaction independently. Moreover, cheap liquid-electronic carriers instead of Pt based noble metal catalysts also make the system cheaper. The performance of MEDFC depends greatly on the electron carriers. Based on thermodynamics principles, the stand potential of the anode electron carrier ought to be modestlyabove the stand potential of the fuel. Similarly, the stand potential of the cathode electron carrier ought to be modestlybelow the stand potential of the oxygen reduction reaction. The electron carriers require rapid electron transfer dynamics to reduce the overpotential from a kinetic perspective. Moreover, the solubility and stability of the electron carriers need to be considered to ensure that the cell can maintain a high energy output for a relatively long time. Some recently reported works on MEDFCs fueled with biomass or biomass derived compounds for electricity generation are listed in Table 7 . In 2006, Larsson reported a high-power carbohydrate fuel cell using V3+/VO2+ as anode electron carriers, and VO2+/VO2+ as cathode electron carriers. This way of using biomass for electricity production avoids the Carnot cycle losses in heat engines [222]. In 2014, Liu et al. reported MEDFC cells fueled by lignocellulose and its derivatives. The systems employ polyoxometalates (POMs) as an anode electron carrier, which grab electrons from various organisms under illumination [223]. A self-breathing air cathode is employed in this system and the maximum power density (P max) is 0.72 mW/cm2 [224]. Under illumination, an intermolecular charge transfer complex is formed leading to photo-excited electrons and holes in separation, which then stabilizes the reduced state of POM. The Pmax of the POM-MEDFC system can be further improved to 51 mW cm−2 using phosphomolybdic aicd as the cathode electron carriers [220]. Fe3+/Fe2+ species are cheap and have relatively good electrochemical activity. The stand potential of Fe3+/Fe2+ species are 0.77 V vs. RHE, hence the Fe3+/Fe2+ species can be used both anode electron carriers to oxidise biomass and cathode electron carriers to react with oxygen. Gong et al. reported a MEDFC system with Fe3+/Fe2+ species as the anode electron carrier with a P max of 100 mW cm−2. Kinetic experiments show that the reaction of Fe3+ oxidized glucose is a first-order kinetic reaction, and its apparent rate constant is 127.85 kJ mol−1 . Zu et al. constructed a symmetrical MEDFC system with a power density of 30.8 mW/cm2 using Fe3+/Fe2+ species as electron carriers in both sides [226]. In recent years, the introduction of organic active species has greatly expanded the screening range of electroactive species in redox flow batteries. By rational design of molecular structure, the chemical properties like stand potential, solubility and stability need to be able to be adjusted conveniently [227]. Zhao’s group introduced methylene blue, an electromechanical active species, as an anode electron carrier, and designed a MEDFC system that can work in a wide pH range. The P max under acidic and alkali conditions reached 12.3 and 41.8 mW cm− 2 with open circuit voltages of 560 and 1560 mV, respectively. Under alkaline conditions, the solubility of lignin increases, which can further reduce the mass transfer resistance and improve the battery performance [174]. Ideally, the ultimate products of fuels in MEDFC are CO2 and water in order to achieve the maximum conversion of chemical energy of the fuel to electric energy. It is indispensable to analyze the oxidation process of the fuel in order to improve the performance of MEDFC. Part of the fuel was completely oxidized to CO2, while formic acid, glycolic acid, HMF, furfural and other incomplete oxidation products were also detected when biomass was used as the fuel [220]. H3PMo12O40 can oxidize lignin to benzoic acid, vanillin and vanilic acid [228]. Glucose is oxidized to formic acid and acetic acid by H3PW11MoO40 [223]. Untreated raw lignocellulose like wheat straw and bagasse has complex structures and exhibit strong chemical stability. Thanks to the high chemical activity of the electron carriers, although it is difficult to completely oxidize untreated lignocellulose to CO2, the electron carriers indeed destroy the stable structure of lignocellulose and improve the accessibility of cellulose by primarily degrading lignin and hemicellulose [229]. Therefore, MEDFC can be coupled with the pretreatment process for bioethanol production. With the pretreatment as the “charging” process, the residue of biomass after pretreatment is suitable for the subsequent enzymatic hydrolysis and fermentation to produce ethanol. Thereby, both ethanol fuel and electricity can be produced using untreated biomass as feedstock under mild conditions. This technology provides a new idea and approach for the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass [230]. MEDFC is a promising technology. The introduction of liquid electron carriers solves the problem that untreated biomass is insolubleinwater. The expensive pretreatment process of fuel is unnecessary for MEDFC, which makes MEDFC a more economical device compared to MFC and DCFC. In summary, the direct utilization of biomass energy by the MEDFC system offers a more economical, environmentally friendly, reliable and sustainable option. At present, MEDFC is still in the early stage of laboratory scale research, and more in-depth researches are needed in the aspects of stack design, performance optimization, electronic carrier selection and mechanism analysis. There are just a few papers on the mechanism of the reaction between the electron carrier and biomass. Only by fully understanding the real chemical reaction process between the electronic carrier and the biomass can the efficient conversion process from biomass to electricity be realized under mild conditions. 5 Lignocellulosic biomass as sustainable materials for energy storage More and more attention has been paid to use the natural raw lignocellulosic biomass and its isolated components as emerging materials for electrochemical energy storage (EES) devices. This is due to their mechanical properties, intrinsic microstructures and chemical activities despite the highly attractive properties of being readily available, sustainable and environmental-friendly [4,234–237]. EES devices, including supercapacitors (SCs), lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and other rechargeable batteries, are widely studied to achieve lower cost, better security and higher performance for the growing energy demands for intermittent renewable energy storage, electric vehicles and portable electronic devices [238,239]. Novel materials with good electrochemical and mechanical properties, specific structures and low cost are desired to obtain practical EES devices with high capacity, long service life and good security. An overview of the application of lignocellulosic biomass, including cellulose, lignin, natural plants and their derivatives, in EES devices is presented in Fig. 6 . Generally, these materials contribute to the core components of EES devices from electrodes to electrolytes, usually functioning in the forms of carbons or polymers. Because of its relatively high carbon content, lignocellulosic biomass is a sustainable and potential electrode material with good electrical conductivity after simple carbonization. Meanwhile, the typical hierarchical porous structure of naturally raw biomass can be inherited by derived materials [234,240,241], endowing the new materials a large surface area and porous structure which are vitally beneficial to achieve active electrode reactions and efficient ionic transfer. Moreover, with heteroatoms such as O [242–245] and N [246–253] of particular electrochemical functions doped in the carbon framework, the derived materials are capable of exhibiting outstanding performances. When incorporated into EES devices as biopolymers, the inherent mechanical strengths of lignocellulose impart the components with stability [236,240]. Besides, abundant oxygen-containing groups on the surface can provide effective hydrogen-bond interactions with other components, leading to not only high operational stability but good electrolyte wettability as well [254–256]. Additionally, chemically active groups enable lignocellulose to be accessible for modification with diverse functional materials to construct the expected composite materials [256–259]. 5.1 Application of lignocellulose-derived materials in supercapacitors SCs with high power density and long lifecycle have attracted significant attention. A SC consists of two electrodes, an electrolyte, and a separator. SCs storing energy based on reversible ion adsorption at the electrode–electrolyte interface are called electrochemical double layer capacitors (EDLCs), and the ones storing charge by fast surface redox reactions are named pseudocapacitors [260,261]. The EDLC electrodes are usually carbonaceous materials and present good cyclic stability, while electrodes for the latter containing electrochemically active materials exhibit high specific capacitance. For SC electrodes, materials with good conductivity, highly porous structures and certain mechanical strength are desired [261]. With regard to separator and electrolyte, good ionic conductivity and thermal/chemical/mechanical stability are critical factors [262]. Lignocellulose can be converted to carbon materials or integrated with active materials to construct electrodes, and can also be processed as separator materials for supercapacitors. 5.1.1 As carbon electrodes Carbon materials with large specific surface area (SSA), hierarchical pores and good conductivity are capable of providing EDLCs electrodes with exceptional capacitance, rate performance and cyclic stability. Researchers have prepared immense carbon materials from precursors with various morphologies and chemical compositions from lignocellulose [235–237] through facile processes such as hydrothermal treatment, heteroatoms doping, carbonization and activation. Notably carbonization-activation approaches were most commonly applied to prepare carbon materials in this section. During these processes, several variants significantly influence the properties of the carbon materials, including carbonization temperature and method of activation. Carbonization is usually conducted between 400 °C and 1000 °C. Mass yield decreases and pore volume increases with the rising of carbonization temperature due to an intensified pyrolysis, therefore higher porosity and surface area could be obtained [263]. Meanwhile, the graphitization degree of the carbon material will be enhanced so that a better electrical conductivity will be achieved [264]. Besides, the carbonization temperature has an impact on the contents of oxygen and nitrogen functional groups which can serve as the active sites providing extra pseudocapacitance [263]. In the activation procedure, abundant channels and pores form on the surface and inside of the material which are capable of being modulated by the mass ratio of activating agent [265,266] and the time of treatment [267]. Hierarchically macro/meso/microporous structure and high SSA induced by the etching effect of activating agent enable electrolyte ions to transfer quickly and be stored efficiently [268], thus enhancing the capacitance and rate performance of the electrodes. Some examples of lignocellulose-derived carbon electrodes classified by precursor materials are summarized in Table 8 with key information including their structural properties, carbonization approaches and electrochemical performances. 5.1.1.1 Cellulose-derived carbon Cellulose and its derivatives are prompt sustainable precursors for carbon electrodes due to their abundant carbon contents. Additionally, previous structuring of cellulose is possible to fabricate advanced materials with elaborately porous morphologies. Nitrogen-doped hierarchically porous carbon (NHPC) [247] material has been synthesized through one-pot carbonization from MCC/ NaOH/urea mixture and revealed a high SSA of 2245 m2 g−1 with an appropriate average pore size of 2.83 nm. The resultant symmetrical capacitor showed excellent electrochemical performances with a capacitance of 300 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, a high energy density of 17.2 Wh kg−1 at 452 W kg−1 and a stable cyclic capacitance remaining of 95% after 10,000 cycles. It is worthy of attention that aerogels are three-dimensional (3D) porous materials with inner-connected networks, leading to high surface areas and hierarchical porous structures. Zu et al. [270] synthesized high-surface-area carbon aerogels (CA-SCD) from cellulose microcrystalline/NaOH solution by gelation, regeneration, supercritical CO2 drying and CO2 activation. As shown in Fig. 7 (a)–(c), the interconnected 3D construct of nanocellulose gels was preserved by carbon aerogels which attained a high specific surface area of 1873 m2 g−1 and a high pore volume of 1.80 cm3 g−1, and delivered excellent specific capacitances of 302 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and 205 F g−1 at 20 A g−1. Likewise, carbon aerogels were prepared from sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) [267]. After KOH activation, the CA obtained a highly porous and interconnected 3D nanostructure, as illustrated in Fig. 7(d and e), which enhanced conductivity and ion transportation. The carbon aerogel that had been activated for 3 h (aCA-3 h) reached outstanding electrochemical properties and a capacitance of 152.6 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1. Besides, wood cellulose nanofibers (CNFs)-derived carbon nanofiber aerogels [264] synthesized via a TsOH catalysed pyrolysis process delivered an excellent electrical conductivity of 116 S m−1. Additionally, nitrogen-doped carbon fibers/GO aerogels (NCGA) [246] were prepared from a mixture of NFCs, graphene oxide (GO) and ethylenediamine, as illustrated in Fig. 7(f), where NFCs played the role of construction enhancer. NCGA exhibited a capacitance of 289 F g−1 at 5 mV s−1 and a retainment of 90.5% after 5000 cycles at 3 A g−1. Moreover, Hu’s group [269] has assembled an all-nanofiber asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC) by employing MCC-derived hierarchical porous carbon aerogel (HPC) as anode and cathode conductive matrix. The 3D porous structure comprising cross-linking nanofibers facilitated high performances of the ASC such that the capacitance was 64.83 F g−1 at 0.25 A g−1, and the energy density 23.05 Wh kg−1 at 213 W kg−1. These findings have revealed that cellulose-derived carbon aerogels present a promising direction toward green and high-performance SCs on account of the facile preparation approaches and their interconnected skeletons with hierarchical porous structures which accelerate the transfer of both electrons and electrolyte. 5.1.1.2 Lignin-derived carbon Lignin-derived carbon materials of diverse structures have been prepared from various isolated lignin products. Rod-shape porous carbons [263] were synthesized from aniline modified lignin and their structural properties could be modulated by carbonization temperature. Lignin-derived 2D carbon nanosheets (CNSs) [244] containing 11 wt% oxygen were constructed via freeze-casting and carbonization, and showed a high capacitance of 281 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 favored by the pseudocapacitance contribution from the oxygen heteroatom. Lignin-based hierarchical porous carbon microspheres (HPCMs) [271] were fabricated by an inverse phase dehydration method in which K2CO3 played a role of pH regulator as well as template and activating agent in further carbonization. The obtained HPCMs electrode exhibited a capacitance of 140 F g−1 at 0.05 A g−1 in organic electrolyte. Besides, nitrogen-doped hierarchical 3D carbons [249] rich in micropores, favorable mesopores and interconnected macropores were prepared by a hydrothermal crosslinking reaction and KOH activation, and exhibited a high specific capacitance of 440 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1. Particularly, Chen et al. [272] prepared lignin-based porous carbon (LPC) with rich mesopores and a hybrid oxygen content of 16.5% through a one-step method of microwave heating combined with the use of humidified nitrogen and obtained a high-performance supercapacitor. Zhang et al. [248] constructed an interconnected hierarchical porous nitrogen-doped carbon (HPNC) by using lignin-derived byproducts from bioethanol production, containing proteins which provided nitrogen sources during a hydrothermal treatment. The resulting HPNC electrode showed superb supercapacitive performances including a specific capacitance of 312 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, 81% capacitance retention at 80 A g−1, and 98% initial capacitance after 20 000 cycles at 10 A g−1. Moreover, HPNC-based supercapacitors in an ionic liquid (EMI-BF4) electrolyte revealed an energy density of 44.7 Wh kg−1 at 73.1 kW kg−1. Likewise, by exploiting enzymatic hydrolysis lignin generated from butanol fermentation, porous carbon [265] was obtained via hydrothermal carbonization and chemical activation with different KOH mass rate from, and realized 3D hierarchical porous texture, a high conductivity of 5.4 S cm−1 and outstanding electrochemical properties. It was proved that these carbon materials with high performances in SC electrodes seemed to be potential high-value products derived from the lignin byproduct. Lignin-derived carbons tend to reveal feasible conductivity. Converting lignin to carbons for electrodes could be a viable way to promote the utilization of this abundant but low-level biopolymer that is usually discarded or just burnt for energy recovery in paper mills. 5.1.1.3 Natural biomass-derived carbon In addition, various carbon materials synthesized from readily available, sustainable natural lignocellulosic biomass sources such as wood, crop stem, straw, fruit shell and leaf [237,276,277] have been applied in SCs electrodes and have reached considerable electrochemical properties. It is inspiring that using lignocellulosic raw materials to prepare such carbon electrodes with the intrinsic porous structures of raw biomass preserved, could be considered as a convenient and ingenious top-down fabrication method [234]. By exploiting straw waste with a tubular structure, a 3D hollow porous carbon (SCPC) [266] was synthesized via self-templating carbonization and NaOH activation. The SCPC achieved a specific surface area up to 2781 m2 g−1 and showed high capacitances of 312.57 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and 281.32 F g−1 at 15 A g−1, as well as outstanding capacitance retention of 92.93% after 20,000 cycles at 1 A g−1. Additionally, a hierarchically porous structure of wood has functioned effectively in SCs electrodes. Beech wood block has been pyrolyzed and then activated by steam to prepare monolithic biocarbon [273]. The resultant carbon delivered a capacitance of 185 F g−1 at 0.15 A g−1 when used as a binder-free electrode. Hu’s group [274] synthesized activated wood carbon (AWC) which exhibited a capacitance of 2.802 F cm−2 at 20 mA cm−2 facilitated by the desirable thickness and direct channels with low tortuosity of AWC, the former contributing to a high area mass loading (up to 30 mg cm−2 for the MnO2/wood carbon anode) and the latter giving rise to high electronic and ionic conductivity. Similarly, Wang et al. [275] fabricated hierarchically porous carbonized wood (CW) and attained a capacitance of 1.934 F cm−2 at 20 mA cm−2. To summarize, carbon materials prepared from isolated cellulose, lignin and raw lignocellulosic biomass with high SSA, high electrical conductivity and porous structures have displayed promising performance as SCs electrodes. Carbonization and activation conditions significantly affected the chemistry and morphologies of the carbons. Their microstructures obtained from specific precursors, of which cellulose gel and natural raw materials should be highlighted, resulted in large SSA and hierarchical pores, and consequently, led to good electrochemical performances of high capacitance and outstanding rate capability, along with stable cyclic property. 5.1.2 As composited electrodes When containing battery-like electrochemically active materials such as transition-metal oxides and conductive polymers, an electrode can attain pseudocapacitance leading to higher capacitance, a large operating voltage window, and far superior energy density, compared with a carbon electrode [260]. Due to their appealing mechanical properties and chemical activity, lignocellulosic biomasses have been incorporated with various electrode materials to prepare high-performance pseudocapacitive electrodes. Here some lignocellulose-derived carbons applied in composited pseudocapacitive electrodes for ASCs were reviewed. 5.1.2.1 As conductive matrix for mental oxides In a pseudocapacitive electrode containing transition-metal oxides, a matrix is required to enhance conductivity and to provide a porous framework. Lignocellulosic biomass derived carbon materials exploited as a matrix have presented dependable performances. Cotton stalk-derived carbon fiber@Ni-Al layered double hydroxide nanosheets [278] exhibited a high specific capacitance of 1214.9 F g−1 because the carbon fibers could prevent aggregation of the Ni-Al layered double hydroxide, as well as enhancing the electrical conductivity. A nanocellulose-enabled, all-nanofiber ASC mentioned above [269], of which the cathode was comprised of nanocellulose carbon aerogel and NiCo2O4 (HPC/NiCo2O4), demonstrated a splendid capacitance of 10.84 F cm−2 at 0.25 A g−1 attributed to the highly conductive 3D interconnected fibril networks and hierarchical pores that facilitated the transfer of both electron and electrolyte. Besides, a lignin-derived hierarchical mesoporous carbon nanosphere with in-situ embedding of NiO nanoparticles of 11 wt% demonstrated a surface area of 852 m2 g−1 and exhibited an exceptional capacitance of 508 F g−1 [279]. In addition, a lignin-derived carbon/zinc oxide (LDC/ZnO) composite [280] was synthesized via a facile electrostatic self-assembling carbonization process and displayed a high capacitance of 193 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1. The lignin-derived nanosheets encased the ZnO nanoparticles and offered a high pore volume and large SSA. Moreover, wood –derived composited electrodes have gained intense interests for the inherently straight channels of wood ideally suited for fast mass transport. Wood-derived carbon can also preserve the good mechanical strength of raw wood. Hu’s group [274] fabricated a MnO2@WC cathode via in situ anodizing growing of MnO2 on the surface of activated wood carbon (AWC) mentioned above. MnO2@WC and AWC have been integrated into an all-wood-structured ASC together with a wood membrane separator. A high energy density of 1.6 mW h cm−2 and a power density of 24 W cm−2 were boosted by the low-tortuosity channels of AWC which enabled a high mass loading and fast ionic transport. Another all-solid-state ASC assembled with carbonized wood (CW) and Co(OH)2@CW composite [275] which was prepared through electrodeposition exhibited an energy density of 0.69 mW h cm−2 at a power density of 1.126 W cm−2. Additionally, by electrodepositing FeOOH nanosheets and coating a conductive poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) network on CW [281], the composite electrode achieved an enhanced capacitance of 1167 F g−1, 45% of the theoretical capacity of FeOOH (2606 F g−1). Therefore, owing to the porous structures of carbon matrixes that improve the electrical conductivity and ionic transfer and also provide a large interface area, pseudocapacitive electrodes with lignocellulosic carbons in SCs can usually achieve higher performances. 5.1.2.2 As flexible polymer substrate for metal oxides In the booming area of solid-state flexible SCs, substrate materials with high flexibility, highly porous structures and low cost are desired. Liang’ s group explored lignin-derived materials with exceptional properties. With the Al/activated carbon/lig-MnO2 anode prepared via depositing MnO2 on activated carbon with lignin as a substrate [282], the ASC obtained a capacitance of 5.52 mF cm−2 at 6.01 mA g−1. In another case, lignin integrated with MiWO4 nanoparticles and Al substrate was used as an Al/lig–NiWO4 as anode [283] in a quasi-solid state flexible ASC and reached a capacitance of 17.01 mF cm−2 at 0.13 A g−1. With regard to their attractive flexibility and mechanical toughness, cellulose-derived materials have been composited with other carbon materials and electrochemically active materials for flexible electrodes and have revealed much more favorable properties. Zou et al. [284] reported a free-standing and flexible cellulose/RGO/AgNPs composite film electrode fabricated through chemical reduction and filtration. In the as-made flexible film, cellulose served as backbone. Assembled by such two film electrodes, a symmetric flexible all-solid-state supercapacitor delivered a comparatively high capacitance of 683.8 mF cm−2 and energy density of 95.0 μWh cm−2 as shown in Fig. 8 (a–d). A multilayer composite paper electrode [285] consisting of copper, cuprous oxide and graphite assembled on cellulose fibers was manufactured via an easily-operated pencil-drawing-electrodeposition-electro-oxidation as illustrated in Fig. 8(e). The core–shell structure of the composite paper facilitated electrochemical reactions and therefore demonstrated an excellent capacitance of 601 F g−1 at 2 A g−1 and showed admirable retainment of 83% at 100 A g−1. When assembled with carbon paper, as shown in Fig. 8(f), the ASC achieved a remarkable capacitance of 122 mF cm−2 and outstanding cycling stability. By ligand-mediated layer-by-layer assembly, a cellulose paper was incorporated with Au nanoparticles to build a highly porous metal-like cellulose paper (MP) [286] with extremely remarkable power density of 15.1 mW cm−2 at ~128.9 kW kg−1, attributed to the porous MPs used as an effective reservoir for the incorporation of high-energy PC NPs. With all those high-performance flexible SCs, cellulose-derived films or membranes have been manifested to be an encouraging eco-friendly and low-cost substrate for solid-state flexible SCs on account of their outstanding mechanical properties and rigid stability [240]. 5.1.2.3 As substrate for conductive polymers Cellulose could be a good substrate for conductive polymers owing to its abundant original active hydroxyl groups, making it possible and convenient for chemical modification to bind with conductive polymers. Modified with ammine groups in advance and followed by polypyrrole (PPy) polymerization on the surface, conductive nanocellulose fibers composites (PPy-NCF) that maintained most of the micro- and mesopores of the initial NCF, were developed as SC electrodes [257]. These conducting cellulose-supporting polymer electrodes with active mass loadings as high as 9 mg cm−2 presented a considerable capacity of 127 F g−1. Lyu et al. [287] prepared polyaniline (PANI) composited electrodes (PANI/CMCNT) via layer-by-layer (LbL) assembling with a porous cellulose aerogel as the substrate. Owing to the uniformly distributed multilayer nanoarchitecture and interpenetrating channels, a high specific capacitance of 716.62 F g−1 was obtained in a three-electrode test. Via an ionic liquid processed supramolecular assembly, a flexible and conductive cellulose/PEDOT:poly(styrene sulfonate) (PSS) composite matrix was synthesized [288], and then incorporated with multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs). The resultant flexible film demonstrated a good conductivity and a high specific capacitance of 485 F g−1 at 1 A g−1. Moreover, lignin sulfonate has been combined with PEDOT as dopant and surfactant to fabricate PEDOT/Lig biocomposites [243] via oxidative chemical and electrochemical polymerization. The PEDOT/Lig obtained a capacitance of 170 F g−1 which was double to that of reference PEDOT electrodes as a result of additional pseudocapacitance generated by the quinone moieties in lignin. Lignin itself could be a potential active pseudocapacitance material [242,245] considering the hydroquinone/quinone redox cycles. Therefore, a lignin-based substrate could benefit the electrochemical performance of SCs. 5.1.3 As separators and electrolyte reservoirs Porous cellulose materials being capable of absorbing amounts of aqueous electrolyte are considered to be potential electrolyte reservoirs, as well as separators in view of their high stability and excellent mechanical flexibility. In the nanocellulose-enabled SC [262], a NFC separator was prepared by facile pump filtration and obtained a mesoporous structure featuring a high porosity of ~59%, and a high electrolyte uptake of 770%, which raised the quick delivery of ions with an ionic conductivity (0.265 S cm−1). It has been noted that highly porous cellulose fibers are able to function as not only substrate but also as internal electrolyte reservoirs [289]. Yu’s group fabricated mesoporous cellulose membranes (mCel-membrane) via a versatile solution-phase inversion process with an ionic liquid solvent [262]. The mCel-membrane has demonstrated a high electrolyte uptake of 451.2 wt% and a high ionic conductivity of 0.325 S cm−1. By incorporating the KOH-saturated membrane with AC electrodes as EDLC, a high capacitance of 110 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 has been achieved. Moreover, a micro-supercapacitor fabricated through directly depositing the electrodes on the mCel-membrane exhibited a high capacitance of 153.34 mF cm−2. Wang et al [290] reported that cellulose-based hydrogel electrolyte could be prepared through an in situ low temperature crosslinking approach with epichlorohydrin as cross-linking agent, and a high capacitance of 98.8 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and a good rate capability of 89.5% at 16 A g−1 could be obtained in a symmetric SC. Therefore, with their nature of being renewable, biodegradable and stable, cellulose-derived films/membranes/gels are proven to be promising candidates for SC electrolytes and separators due to their porous structures, attractive mechanical properties and excellent wettability for electrolytes. In general, lignocellulose-derived materials obtained through diverse manufacturing approaches have demonstrated efficient applications in SCs components and delivered outstanding performances. The carbon derivatives endowed with multiple structures which were tailored by fabrication of precursors and carbonization conditions, exhibiting exceedingly high SSA and hierarchical pores, leading to enhanced electrochemical double layer capacitances. Lignin-derived carbon could obtain feasible conductivities, while cellulose-derived carbon aerogels and naturally structured wood carbons should be remarked for their structural designs. In pseudocapacitors, lignocellulose-derived carbon matrixes bonding firmly with active materials facilitate the electrochemical properties of composited electrodes by their structural support resulting in reinforced conductivity and ion transfer efficiency. The cellulose-derived materials showed encouraging potential for flexible SCs as either electrode substrates or electrolyte-reservoir-functional separators. 5.2 Application of lignocellulose-derived materials in lithium-ion batteries Due to the advantages of a lightweight, long life, high energy density and power density, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used in electric vehicles and portable electronic devices. LIBs realize the charge and discharge process based on the insertion/deintercalation of Li ions transporting between the anode and the cathode [238]. Generally, an LIB is composed of an anode, a cathode, electrolytes and a separator. Electrodes consist of electrochemical active materials, binders, conductive additives and current collectors. The electrolytes are mainly lithium organic salt and the separators are usually porous films. Many researchers aim to promote LIBs to be safer, cheaper and more efficient through redesigning of cell components materials [291,292]. Lignocellulose sources have been exploited as not only porous carbon materials and binders but also as separators and electrolyte reservoirs in LIBs [235,240,293]. Some examples are summarized in Table 9 . 5.2.1 As carbon materials It is essential to develop advanced materials with high capacity and high diffusion rates of lithium ions in order to realize higher energy density and power density. With respect to the advantages of high carbon contents and original porous structures, lignocellulosic biomass sources have been converted into carbon electrodes or current collectors without conductivity additives after direct carbonization. Fabricated through facile fabrication processes of pyrolysis, heteroatomic doping and activation, the derived carbon materials commonly demonstrated good conductivity, abundant electrolyte–electrode interfaces and stable structures. As discussed in Section 5.1.1, carbonization conditions profoundly affect the performance of the electrode materials. The carbonization temperature and activation approach are direct ways to adjust the surface area and porous structures, which determine the interface between electrode and electrolyte, as well as the migration of ions, critical to the capacity and rate property of LIBs. A certain mechanical strength governed by the carbonization temperature is another vital function for electrode material to cope with the large volume variation caused by Li+ insertion, thus reaching low deformability and propelling the stability of the electrode. N-doped and KOH activated CNF aerogel anode materials were produced using NFC extracted from bamboo with different diameters [294]. A CNF of 50 nm in diameter derived N-doped CNF aerogel carbon showed a capacity of 630.7 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 and 289.0 mAh g−1 at 20 A g−1. The 3D structure with hierarchical pores facilitated the high capacity. Additionally, Lignin-based carbon fibers (LCFs) [295] were synthesized via carbonization of melt-spun Kraft lignin and the effects of different carbonization temperatures has been assessed. The mechanical properties of LCFs were confirmed to be dependent on carbonization temperature. LCFs carbonized at 1000 °C exhibited the best strength of 628 MPa and a modulus of 37 GPa, and furthermore, a conductivity of over 140 S cm−1, which contributed to the highest discharge capacity of 355 mA h g−1, a value approaching that of commercial graphitic electrodes. It indicates that lignin is a promising precursor for conductive carbon materials owing to its high aromaticity and carbon content. Qiu’s group [296] recently reported lignin-derived porous carbon (LPC) materials as electrode materials for LIBs from carbonization and K2CO3 activation of different technical lignin sources and explored the effect of lignin resources on the structural, chemical, electrochemical properties of LPC. The results showed that a high molecular weight and low oxygen/carbon (O/C) ratio could benefit the graphitization degree but tended to cause a lower SSA. The LPC derived from enzymatic hydrolysis lignin possessed a SSA of 1680 m2 g−1 and better electrochemical properties in LIBs, donating a capacity of 490 mAh g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1. 5.2.2 As conductive matrixes Combined with cathode/anode active materials, lignocellulose derived carbon materials performed steadily as current collectors and conductive matrixes in LIBs electrodes. A free-standing LiFePO4-carbon paper (LiFePO4@CP) hybrid electrode [298] has been generated by a novel method of simultaneous carbonization of MCC and in situ growing of LiFePO4 shell. This LiFePO4@CP served as a cathode in a flexible LIB without a current collector, polymeric binder or conducting additives and delivered excellent cycling stability for 1000 cycles superior to LiFePO4@Al. Chen et al. [297] prepared an ultrathick 3D carbon framework (CF) current collector by directly carbonizing the natural wood slice. The CF well maintained the unique aligned channels of natural wood, which provided a continuous conductive network for the fast transport of electrons and low-tortuosity pathways for ion transport, leading to a high electronic conductivity of 6.75 S cm−1 and ionic diffusion coefficient of 5.2 × 10−11 cm2 s−1 respectively after lithium iron phosphate materials were infiltrated into the microchannels. With an active material mass loading up to 60 mg cm−2, the electrode delivered a capacity of 7.6 mAh cm−2 (95 Ah L−1 based on volume) at 0.5 mA cm−2 and energy density of 26 mWh cm−2 (323 Wh L−1 based on volume) and good cyclic stability due to low deformability. Through facile mixing and heat treatment at 600 °C, a binder-free SiO x /C composite LIB electrode made of SiO x and Kraft lignin was synthesized and exhibited an excellent capacity maintaining ~900 mAh g−1 as initial after 250 cycles at a rate of 200 mA g−1 attributed to the accommodation of volume change enabled by the flexibility of lignin derived carbon matrix [241]. Chen et al. [299] prepared a self-activated SnO2/C nanocomposite by sintering a hydroxyethyl cellulose (HEC) hydrogen at a low temperature of 300 °C in a tailored atmosphere. SnO2 particles were dispersed evenly and fixed solely in the HEC, as well as in the carbonized composite. Enhanced by the porous carbon layer and oxygen-rich functional group, the composite achieved excellent capacities of 1074 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and 459 at 12.8 A g−1, retaining 656 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 400 cycles. 5.2.3 As binders As biopolymers usually have abundant active oxygen-containing groups, cellulose and lignin and their derived chemicals display a promising perspective as LIBs electrodes binders after modification. Through free radical graft copolymerization of N-methylol acrylamide (NA) and acrylic acid (AA) onto carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), the prepared PNA-NaPAA-g-CMC [256] demonstrated an improved binding ability with both copper current collector and Si particles, a potential anode material, compared with common Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), owing to a high density of carboxyl groups of PAA and CMC and plentiful hydroxyl groups of CMC. These helped maintain the integration of Si and meanwhile assist in building a stable SEI layer. Electrochemical tests revealed a significant strengthening in stability of Si-based LIBs such that 94% capacity was retained after 250 cycles. Likewise, a poly(acrylic acid sodium)-grafted-carboxymethyl cellulose (NaPAA-g-CMC) copolymer worked as a high performance binder for the Si anode [258]. Similarly, an alkali lignin (AL) derived water-soluble binder for the Si anode has been obtained via a free graft copolymerization with polyacrylate (PAA), expressed as PAL-NaPAA [259]. This lignin-derived binder promoted the accommodation of the inevitable volume changes of the silicon anode, contributing to a high capacity retention of 1914 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 840 mA g−1. To develop a 5 V LIBs of high energy density and address the oxidative decomposition of carbonate-based cathode electrolytes that resulted in continuous attack from free radical, Ma et al. [300] presented a renewable lignin binder with numerous phenol groups which could scavenge free radicals and therefore suppress the oxidative decomposition of the electrolyte. The subsequent LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO) cathodes exhibited an outstanding stability after 1000 cycles and retained 94.1% capacity, which was approximately more than double that of the PVDF counterpart (46.2%). 5.2.4 As separators and electrolyte reservoirs A separator in the LIBs is expected to be mechanically rough, flexible, highly porous, electrolyte wettable, thermally stable and chemically inert [254]. Based on this, Li et al. [110] fabricated a highly cross-linked hydroxyapatite nanowires/cellulose fibers (HAP/CF) composited film through facile hierarchical assembling and filtration. The HAP and CFs integrated with each other via hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces. The HAP/CF separator delivered excellent fire resistance and electrolyte wettability and uptake enabled by HAP, and additionally a high flexibility and robust mechanical strength endowed by CFs. A pouch-type LiFePO4/separator/graphite fuel cell incorporated with HAP/CF separator exhibited an enhanced capacity of 135.8 mAh g−1 at 1 C, and capacity retention of 92.3%, contrasted with commercial polypropylene. Gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) combining a polymer separator and liquid electrolyte is a potential solution to the leakage, flame and blast of traditional electrolytes. A green and environment-friendly GPE was fabricated just with lignin fiber and liquid electrolyte via infiltration [301]. The lignin-derived GPE membrane with a porous structure absorbed 230 wt% liquid electrolyte and retained good strength, as presented in Fig. 9 (a–c), while revealing a lithium ion transference number of 0.85. In a Li/lignin-derived GPE/LiFePO4 half-cell, the capacity achieved 165 mAh g−1 (97% of theoretical capacity). Besides, cellulose derived materials have expressed a potential for GPE matrices. Via dissolution, regeneration, and supercritical drying, cellulose aerogel membranes (CMAs) were obtained from cellulose - ionic liquid solution [255]. The CMAs with nanoporous network structures, achieving a porosity up to 94.7% and possessing numerous polar hydroxyl groups, exhibited superior electrolyte uptake as high as 615% and ionic conductivity of 5.76 mS cm−1. In addition to high capacity and cyclic stability, the half-cell contained CMAs displayed a remarkable thermal stability that worked at 120 °C for at least 30 min, enabled by the intrinsic thermal resistance of cellulose. A cellulose skeleton supported poly(propylene carbonate) (PPC) polymer electrolyte [302], as shown in Fig. 9(d–h), prepared by facile solution-casting method was likewise implemented in a 5 V high voltage LIB, and provided pivotal mechanical integrity. Overall, lignocellulose is demonstrated as an attractive renewable material for low-cost, stable LIBs with high energy density. Usually, lignocellulose and its derivative materials used in electrodes are able to supply rational mechanical support for accommodation of the volume change. On one side, lignocellulose-derived carbon materials, usually with porous structures, provide efficient migration of electrolyte ions and electrons. On the other side, when lignocellulose serves as binders or matrixes, the abundant oxygen-containing groups on its surface can enhance the binding with electrochemically active materials, which contributes to the improved stability. Moreover, modifications of cellulose and lignin on active groups endow the derived materials with multifunctional synergistic effects, thus updating the performances of electrodes and GPEs. 5.3 Application of lignocellulose-derived materials in lithium–sulfur batteries Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) battery is an immensely promising EES system for its high theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 which far exceeds the conventional lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery. Moreover, the sulfur sources are abundant, economical and environment-friendly. During the discharge process, also known as the complete reduction of elemental S to Li2S, however, there are several tricky obstacles for the practical application of Li–S batteries; for instance, poor conductivities of elemental S and Li2S, large volumetric expansion and the shuttle phenomenon [303,304]. To address these challenges, enormous efforts have been devoted to the developments of electrodes, separators and electrolytes. Hierarchically structured carbon materials as the carrier of sulfur should be noted for offering good conductivity, cushion volume expansion, as well as confinement of lithium polysulfides [304,305]. Recently, the use of lignocellulosic biomass has presented remarkable performances in Li–S batteries [293,305,306]. Using functionalized carbonaceous electrode materials which possess strong chemisorption for long-chain polysulfides could suppress the shuttle phenomenon. Thus, the cell is able to operate more efficiently and stably. A nitrogen and sulfur dual-doped carbon derived from cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) was reported as an advanced sulfur electrode which possessed strong polysulfide binding [250]. The hybrid carbons were prepared through self-assembling of CNCs, in situ polymerization of polyrhodanine, dispersion of tetraethyl orthosilicate and final pyrolysis. The as-made hybrid carbon exhibited strong polysulfide chemisorption owing to strong Li+–N and Sn 2−–S interactions and a high discharge capacity of 1370 mA h g−1. The synergistic functionalization from the N and S heteroatoms contributed to an ultralow capacity fading of 0.052% per cycle over 1100 cycles. Schneidermann et al. [253] synthesized N-doped carbons by using wood waste or single wood component, urea or melamine, and K2CO3. As carbon source, nitrogen source and activation agent respectively via an eco-friendly solvent-free mechanochemically induced one-pot synthesis. The N-doped carbons achieved a high specific surface area of up to 3000 m2 g−1 and a high nitrogen content up to 12 wt%. A high initial discharge capacity up to 1300 mAh gsulfur −1 was obtained. Similarly, soybean-derived hierarchical porous carbon with intrinsic O- and N-dopants [252] prepared by facile hydrothermal treatment and pyrolysis has been used as sulfur host. By loading a large sulfur mass of 5.5 mg cm−2 and a sulfur content of 80%, the cell showed a capacity of 950 mAh g−1. As indicated above, adequate active sulfur mass loading will enable achievement of high energy density of the Li–S batteries. Therefore, specifically designed matrix and binder materials for sulfur are particularly significant and cellulose could be a competitive candidate. Yu et al. [307] fabricated a freestanding and high mass loaded electrode by a three-step vacuum-assisted filtration method. The electrode achieved a high areal sulfur loading of 8.1 mg cm−2 with the sulfur active layer being sandwiched by a carbon nanotube/nanofibrillated cellulose (CNT/NFC) framework, and exhibited an areal capacity of ≈8 mA h cm−2 and excellent capacity retention of 99.933% per cycle over 1000 discharge/charge cycles, and a high coulombic efficiency of 97.3%. By employing a hierarchically porous carbon-cotton electrode [308] with an ultrahigh sulfur loading of 61.4 mg cm−2, the battery achieved both a high dynamic stability of 70% capacity retention after 100 cycles and a high static capacity retention of above 93% after 60 days. Additionally, cellulose biomass has been exploited as electrolyte separator. A nanoscale microfibrillated cellulose-laden polymethacrylate composite separator [251] which efficiently reserved electrolyte and prevented polysulfide diffusion between cell electrodes demonstrated an excellent ionic conductivity over 1.2 mS cm−1, thermal stability at 200 °C and cycling stability at above 700 mAh g−1. Lee’s group has assembled mechanical flexible nanomat Li-S cells based on bi-layered (pristine cellulose nanofiber (CNF)-anionic CNF) paper separators [309]. These all-fibrous cathode-separator assemblies demonstrated improved redox kinetics, cyclability and provided an energy density of 457 Wh kgcell −1 at 565 Wh Lcell −1. Anyway, for reaching high performances as electrodes and separators, lignocellulosic biomass is considered as an encouraging solution towards the realization of green and reliable high energy Li–S batteries, though more investigation is still needed. 5.4 Application of lignocellulose-derived materials in lithium metal batteries Due to its highest theoretical capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and lowest electrochemical potential (−3.04 V vs. SHE), lithium metal is the most promising anode material for next-generation energy storage [310]. However, there are formidable challenges in practical applications: uneven stripping/plating of Li, infinite volume changes, uncontrollable dendrite growth, reactivity between active Li and electrolyte and cracks and fractures of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), leading to low coulombic efficiency, poor cyclic stability and safety hazard [311]. Lignocellulose biomass provides enormous low-cost naturally structured materials that are capable of serving as protective layers for suppressing dendrite formation and stabilizing the Li anode [312]. A cellulose-based porous membrane that had been used for skin care was exploited in a Li anode [313]. After absorbing electrolyte and being wetted by metal lithium, the cellulose separator promoted a dendrite-free, reversible plating and stripping process of lithium. In addition, carbonized wood (C-wood) with lithium metal infused into its pores was used as a Li/C-wood electrode [314]. On account of the rich straight channels of C-wood that functioned as excellent guides and the 3D framework that minimized the current density, the as-prepared electrode delivered a lower overpotential of 90 mV at 3 mA cm−2 and a better cycling performance than a bare Li metal electrode. Liu et al. [315] proposed a concept of in situ construction of a stable SEI layer by reaction between the Li anode and the functional lignosulfonate layer on the PP separator. Ionic conductivity and mechanical robustness were favored by the synergistic effects of inorganic-rich species and inherited aromatic groups. Therefore, rapid and uniform Li deposition as well as reduced depletion of electrolyte were demonstrated by the reduced voltage polarization of 20 mV and a prolonged cycle life of 80.9% capacity retention after 100 cycles. 6 Conclusions, challenges and perspectives In recent decades, lignocellulosic biomass has been revived as a sustainable feedstock for biofuels production. Though the process for conversion of biomass to fuels is still struggling to commercialization with poor competitiveness to fossil fuels currently or in the near future, definitely biomass-based energy systems will eventually provide a promising energy solution for a sustainable and low-carbon society. Thermo-chemical conversion typically including pyrolysis and gasification has a relatively long history of commercialization since the 1840 s; however, the economic feasibility of these plants are greatly impacted by fossil based gaseous or liquid fuels as well as the cost of coal gasification. The low quality and high acid contents of the bio-oil are the major limitation for the application of biomass pyrolysis oil, and thus upgrading by hydrodeoxygenation is usually necessary. However, routes to obtain cheap hydrogen on a commercial scale are also a problem. Development of efficient but cheap upgrading technology could be the most important direction for the application of the bio-oil. Most likely, a combination of bio-oil upgrading with a conventional petroleum refinery can provide a promising route forward. Bioconversion of lignocellulosic biomass to biofuel such as ethanol has reached commercial scale, but the economic feasibility still has to be improved. This is because the cellulosic ethanol production process is still facing several challenges with regards to the pretreatment, cellulase production, high-solid enzymatic hydrolysis, pentose fermentation as well as process integration for reducing energy consumption. Understanding the biomass recalcitrance at multi-scale is important to the development of efficient pretreatment methods for deconstruction of the cell wall. Development of novel reactors with efficient mixing to improve mass transfer is crucial for enzymatic hydrolysis of pretreated substrates at high solid loading. Efforts also should be made to reduce cellulase production costs, to increase specific activity per weight of cellulase protein, and to improve xylose to ethanol conversion efficiency as well as the tolerance of strain to the inhibitors such as organic acid, furans and phenolic compounds. Research on direct conversion of lignocellulosic biomass to electricity with fuel cell technologies is a new direction for biomass conversion. Theoretically, high energy recovery could be obtained by direct biomass-to-electricity conversion because no external processing is involved. Direct biomass-to-electricity conversion generally can be achieved by mediated fuel cell technology by which electron transfer carriers are used to facilitate electrons flowing from biomass to the final electron acceptor. The efficiency of the cell is limited by the electron transfer efficiency from biomass to electron carriers in the anode, the cell discharging efficiency as well as the electron transfer efficiency from the cathode to the cathode electron carrier. The screening of efficient anode catalysts for electron transfer is the most important factor. However, the kinetics of electron transfer also shows significant impact on the power density of the cell. System optimization in terms of cell structure, operation parameters, kinetics and dynamics analysis should be performed. Lignocellulosic biomass as sustainable materials for EES devices has been developed rapidly in recent years. Cellulose, lignin, natural plants and their derivatives have been explored extensively as materials and components of EES devices owing to their exceptional structures and properties. The lignocellulose-derived materials devices are sustainable, biodegradable, environmentally-friendly and low-cost. Various materials derived from lignocellulosic biomass with chemical/mechanical/structural properties conforming to the demand of EES devices have been found to confer the devices with higher capacities, higher energy/power densities, longer operation lifecycles, and more durable safety. Definitely, lignocellulosic biomass has demonstrated enormous potential as electrodes, substrates, separators and electrolytes with high performances; however, there are still some challenges for their practical applications. First, lignocellulose-derived carbons with irregular porous microstructures are usually obtained through carbonization and activation. The elemental compositions and porous structures of the carbons are profoundly affected by the fabrication conditions. Thus, more rational designs of pore structures and controllable carbonization processes are desired. Second, when acting as matrixes in composited electrodes, the mechanical strengths and hierarchically porous structures of lignocellulose-derived materials synergize with electrochemically active materials, resulting in better performances. Nevertheless, most compositions of the electrodes are physically blended, which could account for the insufficient cyclic stability. Therefore, further studies are needed to reveal the surface properties of substrate materials and their interface interactions with other components. Third, cellulose-derived materials of different structures with high porosities and good flexibilities displayed outstanding performances in solid-state flexible EES devices. To realize more efficient materials, multifunctional modifications on the surface of the derived materials are worth researching. Additionally, considering the natural chemistry and morphology properties of lignocellulosic biomass, a facile top-down method for converting lignocellulose into EES materials is able to preserve the inherent structures and minor elements of the natural precursors. While compositions and morphologies of different biomasses are of tremendous variety, the resultant materials also differ from each other greatly, of which some hardly achieve workable conductivities and mechanical performances. Hence the relationship between the characteristics of biomass precursors and the electrochemical properties of the derived materials need to be further studied. Mater. 30 (2020) 27–33. Miss. Fangqian Wang is currently a Ph. D. student. She received her Bachelor׳s degree in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2017. Her research is now focused on advanced lignocellulose–derived carbon and efficient utilization of lignocellulose biomass through electrochemical methods. Mr. Denghao Ouyang is currently a PhD student in Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China. He received his Bachelor׳s degree in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2018. His current research interest includes the generation of electricity and co-production of high value–added products from lignocellulosic biomass with mediated fuel cell technology. Samuel Page is currently undertaking a PhD (2016–) in the Department of Chemistry, Imperial College London, UK, under the supervision of Dr. Philip Miller. His research is focused upon the development of novel phosphine ligands and transition-metal complexes and their application as catalysts for the hydrogenation of biogenic acids. He joined Dr. Xuebing Zhao at Tsinghua University for a placement in 2018 investigating bio–based dehydration reactions. He obtained his MSci in Chemistry (2011–2016) also from Imperial College London, during which he undertook a one-year industrial placement at Pfizer, UK, investigating new analytical techniques. He is a recipient of a prestigious Imperial College President’s PhD Scholarship. Dr. Dehua Liu is a Professor and Director of Institute of Applied Chemistry, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China. He received his PhD degree in Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University in 1991. His research field of interest includes production of biofuels and bio-chemicals from natural renewable biomass, especially focusing on biodiesel production from oil feedstock and microbial production of 1, 3-propanediol from biodiesel by–product glycerol. He has published more than 250 academic papers. He has been awarded the First Award of the S&T Progress of China Petroleum and Chemical Industry Federation (CPCIF)(2006), “BlueSky Awards” for World’s Leading Technology of Renewable Energy with Best Value of Investment (2016, 2018) and so on. Dr. Xuebing Zhao is an Associate Professor in Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China. He received his PhD degree in Department of Chemical Engineering at Tsinghua University in 2009, and performed his post–doctoral research work at Tsinghua University (2009–2011) and University of Wisconsin-Madison (2014–2015), respectively. His current research interest includes the biorefining of lignocellulosic biomass to produce biofuels and chemicals via chemical and biological approaches. He has published more than 100 peer-reviewed academic papers and book chapters. He was awarded Hou De-Bang Chemical Engineering Science and Technology Youth Award by the Chemical Industry and Engineering Society of China (CIESC) in the year of 2017.

coredata.dc:description: Lignocellulosic biomass has attracted great interest in recent years for energy production due to its renewability and carbon–neutral nature. There are various ways to convert lignocellulose to gaseous, liquid and solid fuels via thermochemical, chemical or biological approaches. Typical biomass derived fuels include syngas, bio-gas, bio-oil, bioethanol and biochar, all of which could be used as fuels for furnace, engine, turbine or fuel cells. Direct biomass fuel cells mediated by various electron carriers provide a new direction of lignocellulose conversion. Various metal and non-metal based carriers have been screened for mediating the electron transfer from biomass to oxygen thus generating electricity. The power density of direct biomass fuel cells can be over 100 mW cm−2, which shows promise for practical applications. Lignocellulose and its isolated components, primarily cellulose and lignin, have also been paid considerable attention as sustainable carbonaceous materials for preparation of electrodes for supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur batteries. In this paper, we have provided a state-of-the-art review on the research progress of lignocellulosic biomass as feedstock and materials for power generation and energy storage focusing on the chemistry aspects of the processes. It was recommended that process integration should be performed to reduce the cost for thermochemical and biological conversion of lignocellulose to biofuels, while efforts should be made to increase efficiency and improve the properties for biomass fuelled fuel cells and biomass derived electrodes for energy storage.
